abstract.text: The propagations of diseases, behaviors and information in real systems are rarely independent to each other, yet they are coevolving with strong interactions. To uncover the dynamical mechanisms, spatio-temporal evolving patterns and critical phenomena of networked coevolution spreading is extremely important, which provides some theoretical foundations for us to control epidemic spreading, to predict collective behaviors in social systems, and so on. The coevolution spreading dynamics in complex networks has thus attracted much attentions in many disciplines. In this review, we introduce recent progresses of coevolution spreading dynamics, emphasizing the contributions from the perspective of statistical mechanics and network science. The theoretical methods, critical phenomena, phase transitions, interacting mechanisms and effects of network topology for four representative types of coevolution spreading mechanisms, including the coevolution of biology contagions, social contagions, epidemic-awareness and epidemicresources, are presented detailedly, and the challenges in this field as well as open issues for future studies are also discussed. , λ QMF c , λ DMP c and simulation results λ c versus network size N are extensively compared for networks with power-law exponent γ D = 2.1 (a) and γ D = 3.5 (b). Theoretical predictions and simulation results for the 56 real-world networks are shown in (c). Reproduced from [103] under CC-BY 3.0.

As shown in Figs. 1(a) and (b) , the MFL and DMP methods yield identical predictions of epidemic thresholds for the SIR model in uncorrelated configuration networks. As for the 56 real-world networks, as shown in Fig. 1(c) , the epidemic thresholds obtained by the DMP method is more accurate because it incorporates full network topology information and some dynamical correlations.

A very important and challenging issue is to reveal the effects of complex topology on networked epidemic spreading. Here we will briefly review the major progresses on this issue, including the effects caused by degree heterogeneity, degree-degree correlation, clustering, finite network size, community structure, weight distribution, multilayer structure and time-varying structure.

Early studies [134, 135] on effects of degree heterogeneity showed that the final epidemic size (i.e., the epidemic prevalence) scales as R ∼ (λ − λ c ) αe near the critical point, with the critical exponent α e = 1 for homogeneous networks, such as ER networks and Watts-Strogatz (WS) networks [20] . In comparison, for Barabási-Abert (BA) networks [19] , R ∼ e −2/λ k , indicating the absence of an epidemic threshold. body_text.text: Propagations in many real-world systems can be theoretically described by spreading dynamics, with infectious disease, computer virus, information, innovation, financial risk and many others being treated as 'epidemics' [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8] . When investigating the spreading dynamics, scientists wish to know some important problems such as what are the dynamical mechanisms behind the phenomena, whether there will be an outbreak, how many individuals will be infected, when an individual will be infected, and how to effectively predict and contain the spreading. Once those problems are well addressed, there are many beneficial aspects for our society. For the governments, the situations of epidemic can be apperceived, and effective containing measures could be provided [9] . For the e-commerce, some personalized recommendation strategies can be designed to promote the diffusion of products (e.g., popular clothing) [10, 11] . For the economics, the financial risks may be perceived in an early stage and thus the global economic crisis could be evaded to some extent [12] .

To address those problems, scientists have already made great efforts since the first mathematical approach to study the spread of an infectious disease by Bernoulli in 1760 [13] . Historically, the single spreading dynamics was put in well-mixed population, without any differences among individuals [14, 15] . Along this idea, researchers can theoretically predict the outbreak size, the critical threshold and the associated critical phenomena.

However, in reality, an individual only has contacts with a limited number of other individuals. Such constrain can be characterized by a network G(V, E), where V and E are sets of nodes and edges, with nodes representing individuals and edges denoting interactions between individuals. Accordingly, scientists studied the single spreading dynamics on oversimplified networks (e.g., regular networks and Erdös-Rényi (ER) [16] random networks), and analytically obtained the outbreak threshold and epidemic prevalence [17, 18] .

The above analytical results are usually far from the empirical observations, because real networks are much more complex than the oversimplified ones. For example, the node degree (i.e., the number of edges of a node) can vary in a few orders of magnitude, exhibiting a highly heterogeneous nature [19] . Other frequently-observed features that cannot be well captured by the oversimplified models include small-world property, community structure, multiplexity, spatiality, temporality, and so on [20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 28, 27, 29, 30] . In a pioneering work [31] , Pastor-Satorras and Vespignani studied the single infectious virus on networks with power-law degree distribution (named as scale-free net-works), and revealed that there is no epidemic threshold. Following this work, researchers found the spreading dynamics, such as global infectious disease, can be better predicted by accounting for more topological features of real networks [32, 33, 34, 35] . Many reviews and books have already summarized the state-ofthe-art progresses in single dynamics [36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41, 28, 42, 43, 44, 45, 46, 30, 47, 29, 48, 49, 50, 51] .

The propagations of diseases, behaviors and information in real world are rarely independent to each other, yet they are coevolving with strong interactions. Coevolution spreading widely exists with important practical relevance [52] . For example, the HIV results in lower immunity of virus carriers, who are therefore more susceptible to infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and hepatitis [53, 54, 55, 56, 57, 58] . The propagation of disease-related information in social media could largely suppress the spreading of the corresponding epidemic disease [59] . An extremely important case is that in the early stage of the spreading of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in China, an unofficial message entitled 'There is a fatal flu in Guangzhou' was send to tens of millions of individuals [60] . As a result, individuals adopted simple but effective actions (e.g., staying home or wearing face masks) to protect themselves from being infected by SARS, which greatly decreases the final number of infected individuals. To uncover and understand the interacting mechanisms, spatio-temporal evolving patterns, critical phenomena and phase transitions of networked coevolution spreading, scientists have already made much efforts. The complex interactions during the coevolving dynamics lead to rich phase transition phenomena and novel physics, such as the coexisting thresholds caused by competitive interactions [61] and the discontinuous phase transition caused by synergetic interactions [62] . In addition, the multiscale structure of networks remarkably affects the criticality of spreading dynamics, not only the value of thresholds, but also the critical exponents [63] and the type of phase transitions [64] . Therefore, the coevolution spreading dynamics on complex networks has attracted increasing attention in recent years.

There are three reasons for us to write this review. Firstly, a large number of papers about coevolution spreading dynamics have emerged recently, but there is still a lack of a comprehensive review to systematically sort out these results, discuss major challenges at the current stage, and point out open issues for future studies. Secondly, the early literature used different ways of expressions to describe essentially the same mathematical problems and methods. It is thus urgent to unify the problem description and the symbolic system. Thirdly, some researchers have already tried to find some potential applications, while these application possibilities are scattered in disparate fields, lacking of integration. Ac-cordingly, this review will be helpful to researchers already in the field, those who intend to enter the field and those who wish to apply the related findings, and this review will also contribute to the further development of the field.

In what follows, we will introduce the progresses of the coevolution spreading on complex networks, including the theoretical methods, critical phenomena, phase transitions, interacting mechanisms, effects of network topology, and so on. Four representative types of networked coevolution spreading are under consideration, including the coevolution of biology contagions, social contagions, awareness-epidemic and resources-epidemic. In Section 2, we will introduce the coevolution spreading of biology contagions, in which each contact between susceptible and infected nodes may trigger the transmission of infection. We mainly focus on the most representative biology contagions, i.e., epidemic spreading. However, in the spreading processes for political information, innovative products and new drugs, a single contact is not enough to eliminate the risk of adopting for susceptible individuals, thus multiple contacts are necessary. The coevolution spreading of social contagions are presented in Section 3, which focuses on the spreading dynamics involving the above social reinforcement effects. To contain the epidemic, some coevlution spreading strategies are developed. In Section 4 and Section 5, we will respectively introduce the coevolution of awareness and epidemic, and the coevolution of resources and epidemic. Finally, in Section 6 we will draw the landscape of this emerging field, summarize representative progresses, and make some outlooks about current challenges and future open issues in this field.

Empirically, the epidemic spreading, virus spreading, and information diffusion are usually modelled as biology contagions, where a single activated source can be sufficient for infection transmission [2, 15, 65] . Susceptible-infectedsusceptible (SIS) and susceptible-infected-recovered (SIR) are the most representative models for biology contagions in networks [15, 66] . For the reversible SIS model, a node can be in susceptible or infected state. At each time step, each infected node tries to transmit the infection to every susceptible neighbor with rate β, and then returns into susceptible with rate γ. For the irreversible SIR model, each infected node also tries to infect every susceptible neighbor with rate β. The difference is that the infected node will then become recovered with rate γ. The recovered node will not participate in the remaining spreading process. The effective transmission rate is denoted as λ = β/γ. Other well-known models for biology contagions include susceptible-infected (SI) model [67, 68] , susceptibleinfected-recovered-susceptible (SIRS) model [69, 70] , contact process [71, 72] , and so on. Without specific statements, this section focuses on SIS and SIR models (others are similar).

Since some reviews have systemically reported the progresses of single contagions on complex networks [37, 41, 42, 73, 74, 75, 76] , we only briefly emphasize two aspects in the following subsections: (i) the mainstream theoretical approaches and results; (ii) the effects of network topology.

In 2001, Pastor-Satorras and Vespignani first studied the epidemic spreading on scale-free networks [77] . They analyzed the surviving probability P s (t) of the viruses data reported by Virus Bulletin covering 50 months, and found P s (t) ∼ exp(−t/τ ), where τ is the characteristic lifetime of the virus strain. Within the traditional framework for well-mixed population of homogeneous networks (e.g., random networks and regular lattices), such long lifetime suggested that the effective transmission rate is much larger than the epidemic threshold. As the same, the average fraction of infected population is very small, which in contrast suggests a small value of effective transmission rate in the traditional framework. To understand this seemingly paradoxical phenomenon, Pastor-Satorras and Vespignani studied the SIS model on Barabási-Albert (BA) networks with power-law degree distribution P (k) ∼ k −3 (see Ref. [19] for the construction of BA networks). Using the heterogeneous mean-field theory, the spreading dynamics is described as

where ρ k is the density of infected nodes with degree k, Θ(t) = 1 k k P (k)kρ k (t) represents the probability that a randomly selected edge points to an infected node, and λ is the effective transmission rate. To simplify the analysis, Pastor-Satorras and Vespignani set β = λ and γ = 1, and thus the first term of Eq. (1) means that all the infected nodes with degree k will become susceptible in the next time step, and the second term stands for the fraction of susceptible nodes with degree k that will be infected by neighbors in this step. In the steady state, dρ k (t)/dt = 0, and the stationary density is

From Eq. (2) , one can conclude that the nodes with larger degrees are of higher probability to be infected. Linearizing around the initial conditions ρ k (0) → 0, the epidemic threshold can be obtained as

where k and k 2 are the first and second moments of the degree distribution P (k), respectively. When λ ≤ λ c , there is no global epidemic; otherwise, i.e., λ > λ c , the global epidemic becomes possible. For homogeneous networks, e.g., ER networks, the epidemic threshold is λ c = 1/( k + 1). For heterogeneous networks with a power-law degree distribution P (k) ∼ k −γ D , in the thermodynamic limit (N → ∞), when the degree exponent γ D ≤ 3, the threshold vanishes due to the divergence of k 2 , and when γ D > 3 there is a finite epidemic threshold. Accordingly, for BA networks, the epidemic threshold λ c → 0 in the thermodynamic limit. Since many real networks are scale-free with power-law exponent no larger than 3 [78] (see also a related interesting comment in Ref. [26] ), their thresholds should be very close to zero and thus a small effective transmission rate can still lead to global epidemic and long lifetime of infected population. The work by Pastor-Satorras and Vespignani [77] inspires a huge number of following studies to reveal different critical behaviors of networked epidemic dynamics, to improve the accuracy of theoretical approaches and to uncover the effects of network topology [79, 80, 81, 82, 41] .

The heterogeneous mean-field theory [77] can accurately captured spreading dynamics on annealed networks [83] , however, it cannot well predict the threshold of quenched networks since these networks usually contains very complicated local structures that cannot be characterized only by the degree distribution. For example, the BA networks [19] and the random Apollonian networks (RANs) [84] are of the same degree distribution but much different structural features and thus different epidemic behaviors. In addition, since Eq. (1) assumes that the states of neighbors are independent, the dynamical correlations among the states of neighbors are neglected, resulting in deviations from real dynamics. To address the above shortcomings in heterogeneous mean-field theory, scientists recently proposed some advanced approaches as follows (see also a recent review [46] about theoretical approaches in networked spreading, as well as related references therein).

By mapping the transmission probability to the bond occupy probability, bond percolation is widely used to analyze epidemic spreading on networks for both the SIR and SIS models [14, 85, 86, 87] , and to identify influential nodes in epidemic dynamics [88, 89, 45] . The final fraction of recovered nodes, goes through a second-order phase transition at the epidemic threshold λ c = k /( k 2 − k ), which is determined by the network structure. Close to λ c , the final epidemic size R behaviors as R ∼ (λ − λ c ) αe , where the critical exponent α e = 1 for ER networks and scale-free networks with power-law exponent γ D ≥ 4, and α e = 1/(γ D − 3) when 3 < γ D < 4 [90] .

To capture the effects caused by quenched topology of an undirected network, the quench mean-field theory [91] , the discrete time Markov chain approach [92] and the N-intertwined approach [93, 94] directly explore the adjacency matrix A, where A ij = 1 when nodes i and j are connected, and A ij = 0 otherwise. Through different approaches, they arrived to the same epidemic threshold

where Λ A is the largest eigenvalue of A. For uncorrelated scale-free networks with a power-law degree distribution P (k) ∼ k −γ D , λ c ∝ k / k 2 when γ D < 2.5, suggesting the same threshold as the heterogeneous mean-field theory. When γ D > 2.5, λ c ∝ 1/ √ k max which indicates that there is no epidemic threshold in the thermodynamic limit [95] , where k max is the maximal degree of the network. Further analyses [91, 96] show that the eigenvector corresponding to Λ A is localized when γ D > 2.5, which means that only hubs and their neighbors are infected, and as a consequence the epidemic grows very slowly and may die out due to fluctuations.

Although the above approaches produce more accurate prediction of epidemic threshold than the heterogeneous mean-field theory, they still cannot well capture the dynamical correlations among the states of neighbors. For example, if there is only one seed node, the dynamical correlations are obvious since the contagion path has the same source, and the epidemic transmission events to one node coming from two neighbors may be correlated [97] . To overcome the weaknesses of the quench mean-field approach but retain its advantages, i.e., to take into consideration the full network structure, the dynamic message-passing approach was proposed by Karrer and Newman [98] to study the SIR model, and generalized later by Shrestha et al. to describe the SIS model [99] . By disallowing a node in the 'cavity' state from transmitting an infection to its neighbors but allows it to be infected by them, the 'echo chamber' [100, 101, 102] (i.e., a node is reinfected by a neighbor it previously infected) is reduced the dynamic message-passing approach. The dynamic message-passing approach predicts the epidemic threshold is λ c = 1/Λ B , where B is the non-backtracking matrix. Note that B is a 2M ×2M nonsymmetrix matrix with rows and columns indexed by directed edges i ← j, where M is the number of edges. The element of B is

where δ jk = 1 if j = k, otherwise δ jk = 0. Recent studies showed that the dynamic message-passing approach well predicts the epidemic spreading dynamics on uncorrelated local-tree like networks [98, 99, 103] , and has also found wide applications in epidemic containing [97] , locating spreading sources [104, 105] , influence maximization [89] , and network dismantling [106, 107, 108] . However, the dynamic message-passing approach needs 2E +N differential equations, which is time-consuming for large networks. And some simplified approaches have been developed, such as edge-based compartmental approach, which only uses 4 differential equations to describe the dynamics, and well predicts the dynamics on configuration networks [109, 110, 111, 112, 113, 114] . The pairwise approximation approach is another well-known approach to capture the dynamic correlations by considering the evolution of pair states, instead of states of individual nodes [115, 116] . It requires k 2 max equations to describe the dynamics even assuming that nodes of the same degree are statistically the same [117, 118, 119, 120] , and if it treats every node differently, N + E equations are needed [121] . It is also too complicated for large-scale networks. Another disadvantage is that the pairwise approximation approach usually cannot show an analytical expression of the epidemic threshold, but just a numerical value. Beside, other approaches were proposed for some specific dynamics, including the master equations [122, 123, 124] , Langevin approach [83] , and other generalized ones [125, 126, 127] . Unfortunately none of these approaches can adequately describe both the full topology of a network and its dynamic correlations. The continuous-time Markov approach produces exact solution for epidemic spreading dynamics by using the transform matrix generator Q q N ×q N , but it can only address several specific models since the generator Q q N ×q N is difficult to be obtained and in practice one cannot solve the N N equations [128, 129, 130, 131] .

It is obvious that different theoretical approaches may yield different epidemic sizes and thresholds for a given epidemic spreading dynamics [82, 103, 132, 133] . Based on the SIS model, Gleeson et al. [132] compared the mean-field predictions with numerical simulation results in 21 real-world networks, and found the accuracy of the mean-field theory is high when the average degree of the nearest neighbors of a random node is sufficiently large. Wang et al. [103] classified the most widely used approaches into three categories: (i) the mean-field like (MFL)

where C, γ D and κ are constants, and Li n (x) is the n-th polylogarithm of x. Degree-degree correlations is an important feature for networks [136, 137, 138, 139] . In an assortative network (i.e., with positive degree-degree correlation), large-degree nodes tend to connect with large-degree nodes and smalldegree nodes tend to connect with small-degree nodes, while in a disassortative network (i.e., with negative degree-degree correlation), large-degree nodes tend to connect with small-degree nodes and vice versa. Boguñá et al. [140] found that the epidemic threshold vanishes in the thermodynamic limit of scale-free networks with power-law exponent 2 < γ D ≤ 3, whatever the two-point degree correlations are assortative or disassortative mixing patterns. Specifically, the epidemic threshold is λ c = 1/Λ m , where Λ m is the largest eigenvalue of the connectivity matrix C kk ′ = kP (k ′ |k) and P (k ′ |k) is the probability that an edge belonging to a node with degree k connects to a node with degree k ′ [141] . Boguñá and Pastor-Satorras further demonstrated the epidemic threshold λ c can be shifted to a finite value when the networks have higher-order correlations [142] . Moreno et al. showed that the assortativity hinders the outbreak size of epidemic spreading [143] . Schläpfer and Buzna found that the spreading dynamics becomes slow in positively (negatively) correlated networks if hubs accelerate (decelerate) the spreading [144] . Recently, Gao et al. considered how to promote the propagation in correlated networks [145] .

Clustering is a widely observed character for disparate networks [146, 147, 148, 149, 150, 151] . Eguíluz and Klemm [152, 153] built a highly-clustered scalefree network model and obtained a finite threshold λ c = 1/( k −1). Eames [154] and Miller [155] also claimed that the clustering reduces epidemic size and increases the epidemic threshold, and Miller [156] further revealed that network clustering is the primary factor in controlling the growth rate of epidemic spreading. However, the effects of clustering seem dependent on the underlying network models, for example, studies on random scale-free networks with high clustering coefficients showed that the high clustering cannot restore a finite epidemic threshold [157] . In a solvable model, Newman theoretically proved that the higher clustering will lead to even lower epidemic threshold since the redundant paths introduced by the triangles in the network provide more opportunities for the susceptible nodes to be infected [158] . Wang et al. [159] revealed that there is a double transition when epidemic spreads on networks with cliques.

Most theoretical analyses are under the thermodynamic limit (i.e., assuming the network size is infinite) while the real-world networks are of finite sizes. Pastor-Satorras and Vespignani [160] studied the finite-size effects on epidemic dynamics in scale-free networks with degree distribution
where f (x) decreases rapidly when x > 1, and k c is the cutoff value. For the case of soft exponential cutoff, i.e., f (x) = exp(−x), the epidemic threshold is

Noël proposed an accurate theoretical framework to address the time evolution of epidemic dynamics on finite size networks [161] . Ferreira et al.. proposed a susceptibility method χ = N( ρ 2 − ρ 2 )/ ρ to locate the network size dependent epidemic threshold λ c (N) for SIS model [162] , where · is the average of assemble, and ρ is the final epidemic outbreak size. They found λ c (N) − λ c (∞) ∼ N −1/ν , where ν is the critical exponent. Some other methods were developed to determine the epidemic thresholds in finite-size networks, such as variability [163, 164] , lifespan [165, 126] and finite-size scaling methods [166, 167, 168] .

Community is a mesoscale measurement of networks topology [169, 170, 171, 172] . Generally speaking, nodes within a community are densely connected while nodes between communities are sparsely connected. Liu and Hu [173] studied the epidemic spreading on simplified community networks and found that the epidemic threshold fulfills λ c (p/q) − λ c (∞) ∼ q/p, where p and q respectively stands for the connecting probability of links within a community and between communities, and λ c (∞) is the outbreak threshold when there are only edges in the communities. Till far, the effects of community structure on spreading dynamics are controversial. Chen et al. [174] found that the overlapping community structure promotes the epidemic prevalence. However, Huang and Li [175] claimed that strong community structure will suppress the epidemic prevalence. Recently, Stegehuis et al. [176] studied the SIR model on real-world networks, and suggested that the community structure can enforce epidemic spreading since some communities are of star-like structure and at the same time, they claimed that community structure may inhibit the spreading since some communities can act as traps for an epidemic process across a network. It is also worth to mention the observation that community structure will dramatically affect the epidemic predictability and variability [177] .

In simple networks, edges are binary (i.e., with existent or not), while in many real networks, interacting strengths between different node pairs are largely different, and thus edges are associated with weights to represent their strengths [178, 179] . Treating a simple network as a special weighted network with each edge associated with weight 1, it is obvious that real weighted networks are always of more heterogeneous weight distributions than that of a simple network. Indeed, scientists have demonstrated that the heterogeneity of weight distribution markedly affect the epidemic dynamics, including both epidemic threshold and epidemic prevalence [180, 181, 182, 183, 184, 185, 186, 187, 188] . Among the earliest works, Yan et al. [180] proposed a simple model for epidemic spreading on weighted networks, where the infection transmission rate through an edge with weight w ij is β ij = (w ij /w max ) αp , where w max is the largest weight of all edges, and α p is a positive parameter. Through extensive numerical simulations based on an artificial weighted network model [189] , Yan et al. [180] showed that nodes with larger strengths (a node's strength is defined by the sum of all weights of its associated edges) are preferential to be infected. Xu et al. [190] proposed a toy model where a fraction f of edges are of weight w 1 and the remaining edges are of weights w 0 ≤ w 1 . For an infected node, it preferences to select a neighbor according to P ij = w ij / j∈N i w ij to transmit the infection with probability β, where N i is the neighbor set of node i. The epidemic prevalence shows a non-monotonic behavior, and the epidemic prevalence drops with f for small f and increases for large f . Cui et al. [191] analyzed a weighted SIS model on six real networks, suggesting that the weight-weight correlation strongly affects the dynamical behaviors: high-weight edges are more significant in keeping high epidemic prevalence when the weight-weight correlation is positive. To accurately predict the epidemic spreading on weighted networks, Kamp et al. [185] and Rattana et al. [186] developed the pairwise approximation approach, which needs O(k 2 max w 2 max ) equations to govern the dynamical system. This method only works if the weights are integers and it is very time-consuming to solve the equations if the weights are broadly distributed. Wang et al. [188] developed a much faster approach for networks with general degree and weight distributions, that is, an edge-weight-based compartmental approach. Their approach produces a remarkable agreement with numerical results. The outbreak threshold decreases with the decreasing of the heterogeneity of weigh distribution, as shown in Fig. 2(a) . Once the average degree k is given, increasing the heterogeneity of degree distribution can promote the epidemic prevalence at small λ while it suppresses the epidemic prevalence at large λ as shown in Fig. 2(b) . Yang and Zhou [183] analyzed a weighted SIS epidemic spreading model on homogeneous networks with heterogeneous weight distribution P w (w) ∼ w −γ W , where γ W is the exponent of weight distribution, w min = 1 and w max = 10 4 are given. They developed an edge-based mean-field theory and revealed that a more homogeneous weight distribution will result in a higher epidemic prevalence.

Some real-world systems are better characterized by multilayer networks (also named as multiplex networks, network of network, interdependent networks in the literature) [28, 43, 192] . A multilayer network is consisted of a few subnetworks (usually two or three subnetworks, each is called a layer), each has its own organizing rules and functions, different from others, while nodes in different layers may have strong interactions that can be described by cross-layer edges. For example, Internet and power grid seem to be two independent networks, but indeed power station supplies electric power to servers of Internet while Internet servers provide some fundamental functions (e.g., control, communication and data ac-quisition) for power stations [193] . Another typical example is transportation systems, where railway networks, air transportation networks and public transportation networks are tightly cooperating to serve for travels [194] . Saumell-Mendiola et al. [195] studied the SIS model on interconnected networks. Through a generalized heterogeneous mean-field theory, they found that the global endemic state may occur even though the epidemics cannot outbreak on each network separately. While for the SIR model on interconnected networks, the epidemic will occur on both subnetworks when the coupling is strong enough, otherwise, a mixed phase exists [196] . In real-world social communication platforms, individuals can only use one of them, such as Twitter, while some individuals may use more than one platforms. If we treat each platform as a subnetwork of multiplex network, those individuals who only use one platform are not exist in all subnetworks (or layers). To investigate how this situation affects the spreading dynamics, Buono et al. [197] assumed that only a fraction of f nodes exist in two layers. In this case, the epidemic threshold is determined by the topology of multiplex networks when f > 0. The epidemic threshold depends on the smaller isolated threshold, i.e., the outbreak threshold when the epidemic spreads on each subnetworks separately, when f → 0. Using an N-intertwined mean-field approximation approach, Wang et al. found that the epidemic threshold is λ c = 1/Λ 1 (A + αB), where Λ 1 (A + αB) is the largest eigenvalue of the matrix A + αB, A and B respectively represents the adjacent matrix of two subnetworks, and α and αλ respectively stands for the infection transmission rate of an edge in and between subnetworks [198] . Cozzo et al. [199] developed a discrete Markovian chain approach to describe the spreading dynamics, and found the epidemic threshold is determined by the maximal value of the isolated leading eigenvalue of two layers. Arruda et al. [200] found epidemic spreading on multilayer networks has localization phenomenon. Recently, Liu et al. [27] constructed two multiplex contact networks from high-resolution sociodemographic data in Italian and Dutch population, and showed that the classical concept of the basic reproduction number is untenable in realistic populations due to the multiplex and clustered contact structure of the population. More recent progresses for epidemic spreading on multilayer networks are presented in reviews [44, 49, 51] .

In some real systems, network topologies are time-varying, which can be described by temporal networks [30, 201] . Karsai et al. [202] proposed an activitydriven network to model the temporal networks, where each node i is assigned an activity potential x i independently drawn from a given probability distribution F (x), and will be active with probability a i ∆t = ηx i ∆t in each time step, where η is a constant. Each active node generates m edges to connect with m randomly selected nodes. At the next time step, all existent edges are deleted and the newly active nodes will generates edges to form a new network. For the SIS model on the proposed temporal networks, the epidemic threshold is λ c = 2 a /( a + a 2 ), where a and a 2 are the first and second moments of a i respectively. The results indicated that temporal networks are more robust to epidemic spreading than integrated static networks. Further analysis on this activity-driven model showed that the memory inhibits the spreading of SIR model while promotes the spreading of SIS model [203] . Nadini et al. [204] revealed that the time-varying modular structure inhibits SIR process, but speeds up SIS process. Karsai et al. [205] found that strong ties in temporal networks suppress the spreading dynamics. Liu et al. [206] studied the SIS spreading process on time-varying multiplex networks, and found that strong multiplexity (i.e., the fraction of overlapping nodes) significantly reduces the epidemic threshold. Valdano et al. [207] proposed an analytical computation approach for the epidemic threshold on temporal networks, yielding an excellent agreement with extensive numerical simulations. Speidel et al. [208] demonstrated that temporal interactions facilitate endemicity of SIS model.

When two biology contagions spread in the same population, the previous contagion may affect the later one, for example, the hosts may be killed or be provided permanent immunity by the first contagion [209, 210, 211] , so that the later one can not infect them.

Newman studied two epidemics spreading on the same network [61] . The first and second epidemics are both described by the standard SIR model, but with different transmissibility probabilities as λ 1 and λ 2 , respectively. The recovery probabilities for both models are simply set as 1. Using the bond percolation approach, the threshold of the first epidemic is

Denoting u as the probability that a node is not infected by a neighbor at the end of the epidemic. On the one hand, the infection has not transmitted through an edge with probability 1 − λ 1 . On the other hand, the infection transmitted through an edge but the endpoint of this edge is not infected with probability λ 1 G 1 (u), where G 1 (x) = k Q(k)x k is the generating function of the excess degree distribution Q(k) = (k + 1)P (k + 1)/ k . Thus, u satisfies the following equation
For a randomly selected node with degree k, it is not infected with probability u k . Therefore, the prevalence of the first epidemic is
where G 0 (x) = k P (k)x k is the generating function of P (k).

At the ending of the first epidemic, the topology of the residual network (i.e., after deleting the nodes that infected by the first epidemic) is obviously changed. The second epidemic can not transmit the infection to the nodes that are infected by the first epidemic, namely the second epidemic can only spread on the residual network. For a node i that is not infected by the first epidemic on the residual network, it connects to m other uninfected nodes with probability P u (m) = 1
And its generating function can be expressed as
Following the bond percolation theory, the threshold of the second epidemic should fulfill the condition F ′

(1) > 1, the system has an additional phase transition, and Newman called it as coexistence transition. The threshold λ 2 c of the second epidemic is thus named as coexistence threshold. The corresponding results on ER networks are shown in Fig. 3 .

Newman and Ferrario [212] further considered another different situation, in which the second epidemic can only infect the nodes that are ever infected by the first epidemic. Their model can be used to describe the case that one disease increases the chance of infection by the second one. For instance, once a person is infected by the syphilis and HSV-2, he/she will be more likely to be infected by HIV [213] . With similar method to Ref. [61] , the second epidemic threshold is

, and λ 1 is the transmission probability of the first epidemic. When λ 1 → λ 1 c = 1/G ′ 1 (1), one obtains λ 2 c = 1. And λ 2 c decreases monotonously with λ 1 , and λ 1 c ≤ λ 2 c ≤ 1. That is to say, the second epidemic threshold is never smaller than the first one.

Bansal and Meyers [214] modeled two consecutive seasonal epidemic, such as influenza, on heterogeneous networks, and the former epidemic inflicts immunity on the later one. At the end of the first epidemic, a fraction of 1 − f infected nodes
The inset shows the two epidemic thresholds as functions of the average degree k . The shaded areas denote that both epidemic can spread. Reproduced from [61] .

by the first epidemic are immune to the second epidemic, and the remaining f infected nodes can be infected by the second epidemic. By using bond percolation theory, Bansal and Meyers studied both the perfect immunity (i.e., f = 0) and partial immunity (i.e., f > 0), and found that the immunity of the first epidemic will limit the outbreak of the second epidemic.

Funk and Jansen [215] considered two SIR epidemic dynamics consecutively spread on an overlay network. The overlay network is constructed by two layers denoted as A and B. Nodes in two layers are the same, and the network size is N. The overlay network is built according to degree distribution P (k 1 , k 2 ), where k 1 and k 2 denote the degrees of a node in two layers respectively. The first epidemic spreads on A with effective transmission probability λ 1 , and then all the nodes being infected by the first epidemic are removed from the overlay network. The second epidemic spread on the residual network with effective transmission probability λ 2 . The generating function G r 0,2 (x) of the residual degree distribution of A on B is
where G J 0 (x, y) = k 1 k 2 P (k 1 , k 2 )x k 1 y k 2 is the generating function of the degree distribution P (k 1 , k 2 ), h 1 = 1

, and k 2 is the average degree of network B. Denoting u 1 as the probability that an edge does not connect to an infected neighbor, which is obtained by solving u 1 = G 1,1 (1 − λ 1 + λ 1 u 1 ), where G 1,1 (x) is the generating function of the excess degree of network A. The parameter h 1 is the probability of a node arrived at following a random edge on B to be infected by the first epidemic. If there is no overlapping between networks A and B, the second epidemic threshold is

Obviously, λ overlay c strictly increasing with q 1|2 , which indicated that overlapping is beneficial for suppressing the second epidemic. Funk and Jansen finally studied a more realistic scenario with partial immunity. They found that once the first epidemic provids partial immunity to the second one, the second epidemic is easier to invade the population. However, when two interacting epidemic simultaneously spread on multilayer networks, Zhou et al. [216] found that overlapped links have no effects on the spreading dynamics, while the fraction of vulnerable nodes markedly affect the dynamics.

In many real-world scenarios, epidemics are spreading simultaneously, instead of strictly one after the other [217] . This subsection reviews some representative models about the coevolution epidemic spreading dynamics.

Newman and Ferrario investigated the behavior of two competing SIR-type epidemics on the same network [218] . Denoting the two epidemics as red and blue epidemics with transmissibilities λ 1 and λ 2 respectively. Each node can only be infected by one of the two epidemics. Initially, a seed node for each epidemic is randomly selected. Assuming that the blue epidemic evolves with time-step 1, Figure 4 : (Color online) Phase diagram of the system with a given λ 2 . The colors represent the dominant disease, and the colored symbols represent leading-order scaling of the expected number of individuals infected by each epidemic. Reproduced from [218] . and red epidemic spreads with time-step 0 ≤ α ≤ 1. Newman and Ferrario developed the competing percolation to study the final state of the two epidemics theoretically. In the thermodynamic limit, the faster epidemic first spreads on the networks, and the slower one spreads on the residual networks. At time t, the average number of nodes infected by the blue epidemic is N b = e tlnR b , where R b = λ 2 /λ c is the reproductive number for the blue epidemic, and λ c = k /( k 2 − k ). Similarly, the average number of infected nodes by red epidemic at time t is N r = e tlnRr/α , where R r = λ 1 /λ c is the reproductive number for the red epidemic. Initially, the two epidemics increase exponentially. Defining β 0 as the ratio of the growth rates of the two epidemic as
body_text.section: Two competing or cross-immunity biology contagions

body_text.text: For the case of β 0 > 1 the red epidemic spreads faster, when β 0 < 1 the blue epidemic spreads faster. The growth-rate boundary, i.e., β 0 = 1, is thus α = ln(λ 1 /λ c )/ln(λ 2 /λ c ). According to the competing percolation theory, the phase diagram of the system is shown in Fig. 4 , where λ x = λ 2 ln k λ 2 /( k λ 2 − 1). Miller [219] developed a generalized edge-based compartmental approach to describe the two SIR competing spreading dynamics. Considering the effects of mobility of individuals, Poletto et al. proposed a novel model with two competing epidemics in a metapopulation network [220] , and found the mobility of hosts across patches affects the infectious period of the dominance epidemic. Poletto et al. [221] further revealed that mobility can either have no effect on the competition dynamics or plays an important role in sharping the dominant epidemic.
body_text.section: Two competing or cross-immunity biology contagions

body_text.text: For the case of two competing SIS epidemics on complex networks with mutually immune, Prakash et al. found that the stronger epidemic will completely suppress the other [222] . Once the two competing SIS epidemics have partial immunizing functions, there will be a coexistence region of the two epidemics [223] . Bovenkamp et al. studied two competing SIS epidemics on a complete network [224] , and revealed that only one epidemic exists when the transmission probability is above the epidemic threshold, which is markedly different from the observations in competing SIR epidemics. Disallowing the epidemic dies out, that is to say allowing one node becomes infected automatically when there are no infected nodes, the dominating epidemic and dominated epidemic will alternate when the two epidemics are identical. The domination period of an epidemic depends on its initial infected nodes. Two competing epidemics with general infection rates were also analyzed recently [225, 226] .
body_text.section: Two competing or cross-immunity biology contagions

body_text.text: Wang et al. proposed a competing SIS model to describe the idea spreading dynamics [227] . Assuming that the effective transmission rate of the first and second ideas are λ 1 = β 1 /γ 1 and λ 2 = β 2 /γ 2 respectively. If node i is only surrounded by idea 1 (or 2), it will be infected with rate n 1 β 1 (or n 2 β 2 ), where n 1 (or n 2 ) is the number of infected neighbor by idea 1 (or 2). If node i is exposed to both ideas, the infection probabilities are α c β 1 and η c β 2 for idea 1 and idea 2 respectively, where 0 ≤ α c , η c ≤ 1. Through a generalized heterogeneous meanfield theory, Wang et al. found that the system has coexistence region of the two ideas on scale-free networks, and this region dependents on whether the ideas have exclusive or nonexclusive influences.
body_text.section: Two competing or cross-immunity biology contagions

body_text.text: Different epidemics may transmit on distinct networks. By considering this factor, Sahneh and Scoglio proposed a competitive epidemic spreading model SI 1 SI 2 S over arbitrary multilayer networks [228] . In this model, each node can be in one of the three states: susceptible, I 1 (i.e., infected by epidemic 1) and I 2 (i.e., infected by epidemic 2). The two epidemics spread on networks A and B with effective transmission rates λ 1 = β 1 /γ 1 and λ 2 = β 2 /γ 2 respectively, where β 1 (β 2 ) is the transmission rate of epidemic 1 (epidemic 2), and γ 1 (γ 2 ) is the recovery rate of epidemic 1 (epidemic 2). Note that a node can not be infected by two epidemics simultaneously. Using the first-order mean-field approximation, the evolutions of the fraction of infected nodes by epidemics 1 and 2 are respec-

Through bifurcation analysis of the model, the system has four regions when two competing epidemics spreading on multilayer networks. The four regions are epidemic-free, epidemic 1 absolute-dominance, epidemic 2 absolute-dominance, and coexistence regions, as shown in Fig. 5 . When the two layers are identical, there is no coexistence region. For the epidemicfree region, i.e., ρ * 1,i = ρ * 2,i = 0, the system is stable when λ 1 ≤ 1/Λ 1 (A) and λ 2 ≤ 1/Λ 1 (B), where Λ 1 (A) and Λ 1 (B) are the leading eigenvalues of the adjacent matrix A and B, respectively.
