body_text.text: Cooperation between two epidemic spreading dynamics means that a node is infected by one epidemic will increase the probability that this node is infected by the other epidemic. Such cooperative effect is also called as synergy effect. For example, once a person is infected by HIV/AIDS, his/her immunity system will be greatly destroyed, thus the probability that he/she gets infected by systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), syphilis, hepatitis will be increased. Conversely, once a person infected by the later diseases (e.g., SLE) has sex with HIV/AIDS patient, his/her infection probability will increase. Cai et al. [62] proposed a coevolution SIR spreading model with cooperative effect between two epidemics, where a node not yet been infected will be infected by one of the two epidemics with probability λ 1 , and a node being already infected by one epidemic will be infected by the other with probability λ 2 > λ 1 . The two epidemics have the same recovery probability. The recovered nodes acquire immunity against the epidemic they had, but not to the other epidemic. Extensive numerical simulations are performed on ER networks with average degree k = 4. Two order parameters, namely the probability P of forming a giant infected cluster and the fraction ρ of nodes belonging to the giant connected cluster, are used to describe the phase transition. The system undergoes a discontinuous transition with hybrid type. At the critical point, the system already has a finite fraction of infected cluster. The fraction ρ ab of nodes being infected by both epidemics 1 and 2 exhibits a discontinuous phase transition for a give λ 2 , as shown in Fig. 6 . Furthermore, the system undergoes a typical continuous transition on 2-dimensional lattices. Specifically, the critical behavior is P ∼ ρ ab ∼ (λ 1 − λ 1 c ) αe where α e ≈ 5/36. Grassberger et al. further discussed the roles of network topology on the phase transition [229] , and revealed that loops are crucial for the emergence of a discontinuous transition. For cooperative spreading dynamics on 2-dimensional lattices with local contacts or on BA networks, there is no discontinuous transition. However, the discontinuous transition always appears for cooperative contagions on 2-dimensional lattices with long range connection, on 4-dimensional lattices and on ER networks. Chen et al. further investigated the fundamental properties of cooperative contagion processes of two SIS epidemics [230, 231] . Assuming that a node being infected by one epidemic has larger infection rate once it is already infected by another epidemic. Mathematically, assuming the spreading dynamics on well-mixed populations, and the system exhibited discontinuous phase transition. Chen et al. [232] computed the critical parameters by using a mean-field approach, and found two distinct thresholds for system with hysteresis.

Cui et al. [233] further analyzed two cooperative SIR epidemics proposed in Ref. [62] on uncorrelated scale-free networks, and developed a generalized heterogeneous mean-field theory to describe the cooperative spreading dynamics, and found the outbreak threshold is λ 1 c = k /( k 2 − k ), which is the same with the classical epidemic outbreak threshold. Near the critical point, the auxiliary

where R k (∞) is the probability that a node with degree k is in the recovered state when t → ∞, and 1/α e is the critical exponent of the system. The type of phase transition is indeed determined by the values of 1/α e . (i) For the case of the degree exponent 2 < γ D < 3, there is no epidemic threshold, i.e., λ 1 c = 0, and the phase transition is always continuous for any values of cooperativity H = λ 2 /λ 1 . The critical exponent is

there is a critical value H c above which the phase transition is discontinuous, and H c is always larger than 2. For the continuous phase transition, the critical exponent is 1/α e = 1/(γ D − 3). When H = H c , 1/α e = 1. (iii) For the case of γ D > 4, the critical exponent is 1/α e = 1, and the phase transition is continuous when H < H c = 2, otherwise, the system exhibits a discontinuous phase transition. The phase diagram is shown in Fig. 7 . Cui et al. further demonstrated that the discontinuity decreases with clustering through extensive numerical simulations [234] .

Hébert-Dufresne and Althouse proposed a synergistic coinfection model on clustered networks [64] , which is constructed by inducing overlapping community [235] . In their model, a node not yet been infected will be infected by epidemics 1 and 2 with probability λ 1 and λ 2 , respectively. A node being already infected by epidemic 1 (or 2) will be infected by the other with probability λ 1 +∆ (or λ 2 +∆). Hébert-Dufresne and Althouse found that the epidemic spreads faster in clustered networks than on the equivalent random networks, indicating that clustering has an opposite role on the synergistic coinfection spreading dynamics to the single epidemic dynamics.

Azimi-Tafreshi [236] considered the effects of multiplexity on cooperative spreading dynamics, and described the multiplex networks by using a joint degree distribution P (k 1 , k 2 , k 12 ), where k 1 and k 2 respectively denote the number of edges in networks A and B, and k 12 denotes the number of overlapped edges. Assuming both epidemics follow the SIR model, denoted as 1 and 2 respectively. Epidemic 1 (2) spreads through edges A (B) with transmission probability λ 1 (λ 2 ), and spreads through overlapped edge with probability λ 12 , and assume λ 12 > λ 1 λ 2 . By using a generalized percolation theory, the fraction of nodes infected by each epidemic and both epidemics in the final state can be obtained. The system exhibits a tricritical point, and the phase transition changes from continuous to hybrid with the increase of the strength of cooperation. Zhao et al. developed a unified theoretical approach for coevolution spreading dynamics on multiplex networks, which can be used to describe the competition, cooperative, and asymmetrical interactions between two different dynamics [237] .

In biology systems, the variation of a virus could lead to thousands of new viruses, such as influenza virus [238] , HIV [239] , meningitis [240] and dengue [241] . Understanding the statistical mechanics, strain structure and spreading patterns has attracted much attentions, especially in the field of biomedicine and statistical physics. Here we mainly introduce the progresses related to physical science. Abu-Raddad et al. [242] proposed a model consisting of interacting multiple epidemics with the existence of coinfection, cross immunity and arbitrary strain diversity. Assuming that the system has n different epidemics, denoted as H = {1, 2, · · · , n}. Nodes in the recovered and infected states acquire immunity against the epidemic they had, but still susceptible to the rest of epidemics they are not infected. Mathematically, denoting I L J as the set of nodes having been recovered from epidemics set J and infected by epidemics set L. There is no intersection between J and L. The birth rate of susceptible nodes is ι and the death rate is µ. For an epidemic l, its transmissibility rate is β l , its recovery rate is γ l and recovery period is γ −1 l . For each epidemic, the strength of infection can be expressed as Λ i = β i J ⊆H\{i} L⊆H\{{i}} J . Abu-Raddad et al. assumed the

On the right hand of Eq. (23), the third term is the infection rate by epidemic i, the fourth term is the rate that a new node is infected by this epidemic, the fifth term stands for the rate that nodes recovered from an epidemic in L, and the last term is the rate at which nodes recovered from an epidemic not belonging to L will be infected by an epidemic in L. Abu-Raddad et al. further analyzed the final state of the spreading dynamics. Assuming that σ j,l = η j φ l , where η j is the prior cross-immunity rate of being infected by a new epidemic since prior exposure and recovery from j different epidemics in the past, and φ l is the cross-immunity rete of being infected by a new epidemic for a node that is currently infected by l different epidemics.

With the above assumptions, the total prevalence is shown in Fig. 8 . The cross-immunity against coinfection has prominent influence on the multiple epidemics than that of the prior exposure cross-immunity. Gog and Grenfell [56] included the effects of reduced-transmission and polarized immunity into the dynamics of multiple-strains. Polarized immunity means that partial cross-immunity makes some individuals be totally immunized. Specifically, Gog and Grenfell assumed that the system has n different epidemics, denoted as H = {1, 2, · · · , n}. For epidemic l, its infection and recovery rates are β l and γ l respectively. If an individual i is infected by epidemic l, the probability of i to be infected by another epidemic, such as epidemic l ′ , is lower than β l ′ , as (1 − σ ll ′ )β l ′ , suggesting the effect caused by cross-immunity [243, 244] between epidemics l and l ′ . In such a coevolution dynamics, Gog and Grenfell found that the system has a epidemic cluster. If the infectious period is short, there is only one dominant cluster; while for a relatively long infectious period, many clusters coexist and alternate with each other. Recker et al. revealed that transient crossreactive immunity can orchestrate antigenic variation in malaria [245] . Shrestha et al. [246] proposed a statistical inference approach to investigate the stochastic temporal variation, under-reporting and over-aggregation about multiple epidemics.

Juul and Sneppen [247] investigated a multiple epidemic spreading model on 2-dimensional square lattice with periodic boundary conditions with N = L 2 nodes, which is a generalization of their previous model [248] , At each time step, each node i will born a new epidemic l with probability σ. If node i is infected by more than one epidemic, it can only transmit one of its infected epidemics to a neighbor j. If j does not be infected and immunized to epidemic ι, j will be infected by ι. After a period of τ 0 steps, node j recovers. If a node has been infected by n different epidemics and not yet recovered from any of them, the probability that it tries to transmit one of its infected epidemics to a given neighbor is λ = 1 − exp(−τ 0 /4n), which corresponds to the percolation probability. Numerical simulations indicated that the exponent of cluster mass size versus diameter L is close to the fractal dimension of percolation with diameter 1.896.

In the previous section, we reviewed the literature about the coevolution of biology contagions, where whether a contact can successfully transmit the disease is independent to the previous contacts. Therefore, biology contagions are also named as simple contagions. There is another kind of spreading phenomena, such as the diffusion of innovations, the spread of cultural fads, the adoption of behaviors and the outbreak of political protests, where the multiple exposures are required before the adoption because of the validity of its credibility, legitimacy and risk. Thus, a single contact is not enough to trigger the above-stated spreading phenomena, i.e., successive contacts are necessary being interdependent. This class of spreading processes is named as social contagions or complex contagions, which cannot be well captured by simple contagions. The ubiquity of social contagions in the real world demands to revisit most of the dynamical settings and the network structures that have been already addressed. As in the case of the biology contagions, the main concern of this section is also about how different kinds of interplay impacts the coevolution of two or more social contagions, such as the cooperation between two kinds of behavior adoptions.

This section is organized as follows. The first part focus on the single social contagions starting from the empirical studies and the fundamental of the mathematic models. As a generalization of the classical Watts threshold model [249] , we also address the spreading threshold model and introduce the relevant progresses. The interest in this part lies on uncovering how the dynamical mechanisms and the network structures affect the social contagions. The second part is devoted to the interaction of two social contagions. Here, we will revisit the models established to capture the successively and the simultaneously social contagions on complex networks. Our main concern is how the mutual interactions impact the threshold and the type of phase transitions. In the final part, we will generalize the two interacting social contagions to the interactions of multiple social contagions empirically and theoretically. This will be quite challenging since the interactions of them become more complicated and also it is more important since they are widely observed in natural, social and technological systems.

One of the key issues in network science is to understand, predict and finally control the dynamics of social contagion processes on complex networks. As early as in 1973, Granovetter showed that the information spreading through 'weak ties' between casual acquaintances will be faster than it diffusing through 'strong ties' among the close friends [250] . This is because the weak ties are usually the edges connecting distant nodes, which can speed up the spreading. Weak ties theory explained the rapid spread of the HIV disease and information well, however it can not give the reason why it fails when using the contagion of the preventative measures to stop the HIV disease [251] on the same network. This is mainly because of the difference between the spread of the infectious disease and the contagion of the preventative measures, where the former is a simple contagion and one infected individual is sufficient to reproduce the infection, while the latter is a social contagion and the multiple sources of activations are required since this kind of spread is usually uncertain, risky and costly. In this subsection, we will revisit the progress of the empirical analyses that reveal the potential mechanism, i.e., social reinforcement, of social behavior adoptions and the established mathematical models for the single social contagion in complex networks.

The rapid development of the Internet technology makes the large-scale of social experiments on online social networks possible. Centola [252] recruited 1528 participants online and tested the effects of the network structure on the contagion of health behavior. By comparing the health behavior spreading in the regular clustered network and the random network (as shown in the left panel of Fig. 9 ), Centola found the behavior spreads farther and faster across the regular networks than the random networks since the participants can receive the social reinforcement from multiple neighbors in the former network (as presented in the right panel of Fig. 9 ). This is largely different from the results of biology contagions where clustered structure will usually depress the spreading. To investigate the robustness of Centola's experiment, Lü et al. [253] proposed an unknown-knownapproved-exhausted model, which emphasizes the effect of social reinforcement by incorporating the mechanism that the redundant signals can increase the approval rate. They found in some certain conditions, the information spreads faster and broader in regular clustered network than in random network, which to some extent supports the results of Centola's experiments. However, increasing the network size tends to favor the effective spreading in the random network which challenges the validity of the above-mentioned experiment for larger-scale systems. Besides, they found introducing a little randomness into the regular network will yield the most effective information spreading. Similar to Ref. [253] , Zheng et al. [254] further claimed that increasing the network size or decreasing the average degree will enlarge the difference of the final fraction of approved nodes between regular and random networks. Smoking behaviors explicitly bring the effects to the people around the smokers, as a return they also impact the initiation and the cessation of the smoking [255, 256] . Christakis and Fowler studied the effect of peer influences on the quitting behaviors by analyzing a network of 12,067 people who underwent repeated assessments of their smoking behavior and socialnetwork ties over a period of 32 years [257] . They found the likelihood for a smoker to quit smoking behavior depends on their exposures to the multiple contacts of the nonsmokers. The social reinforcement in encouraging smokers to abstain is also found online. Myneni et al. [258] found that smokers are more likely to abstain if they are exposed to several abstinent users by examining peer inter-actions over QuitNet-a social media platform for smokers attempting to quit. A series of other studies also demonstrated that the effects of social reinforcement from the peers were strengthened when the peers come from different social groups, exhibit the value of structural diversity and share some key characteristics with the ego in the dynamics of social contagion [259, 260, 261, 262, 263] .

To popularize the most of the innovations timely, the economists and marketers have been focused on how technological innovations diffuse though a population by performing various controlled experiments. In the developing countries, the adoption of the new agricultural technologies is an important way to help people to get out of poverty. Bandiera and Rasul studied the adoption process of a new crop for the farmers in Mozambique, and found the farmers are more likely to adopt it when they had a higher number of adopters among family and friends [264] . In the diffusion of online innovations, Karsai et al. analyzed a dataset recording the adoption process of the world's largest voice over Internet protocol service-Skype, and found the probability of adoption via social influence is linearly proportional to the fraction of adopting neighbors [265] . The empirical analysis in recruiting the individuals to use Facebook [266] and Twitter [267] indicates that the larger number of exposures that an individual receives, the larger the probability that he/she will adopt the applications.

The social reinforcement effects also existed widely in other kinds of behavioral adoption processes, such as using menstrual cups [268] , adopting seeding strategies [269, 270] , taking a new diagnostic method [271] , joining the social movement activities [272, 273, 274, 275, 276] , retweeting politics hashtags [277, 278, 279] , signing the petition [280] , exchanging user-created content [281] , learning a new industry [282, 283] , and so on.

One early mathematical model established to describe the dynamics of social contagions is the threshold model [249, 284, 285, 286] based on the Markovian process without memory, where the adoption of behaviors depends only on the states of the currently active neighbors (i.e., individuals who have adopted the behavior), and an individual adopts a behavior only when the number or the fraction of his/her active neighbors is equal to or exceeds the adoption threshold. Granovetter [284] proposed the linear threshold model, where all individuals are with states: active or inactive, and an individual becomes active if and only if the current absolute number of active neighbors is equal to or exceeds the corresponding threshold. As the real-world networks are very heterogenous, within the framework of linear threshold, hub nodes are too vulnerable. To fill this weakness, Watts takes into account the heterogeneity of individuals' number of contacts and puts forward a novel threshold model (named as Watts threshold model later) [249] . In the model, each node is initially assigned a threshold φ randomly draw from a distribution h(φ). When the fraction of active neighbors of a node is equal to or exceeds its threshold φ, it becomes active. Adopting the fraction of active neighbors instead of the absolute number is the essential difference compared with linear threshold model. The function h(φ) can be defined arbitrary but satisfies the condition

For an infinite network with finite average degree, the only way that an initial seed node can grow is at least one of its immediate neighbors has a threshold such that φ ≤ 1/k, therein k is the degree of this neighbor. These nodes with φ ≤ 1/k are called vulnerable nodes since it will become active just by one active neighbor. Specifically, for a node of degree k, the probability ρ k that it is vulnerable is
where
By using the method of generation function, the critical condition is

therein, P (k) and k are respectively the degree distribution and the average degree of the network. A remarkable result is that if all individuals are of the same adoption threshold, the final adoption size first grows continuously and then decreases discontinuously as the increase of the average degree. Meanwhile, the global cascade occurs more easily in the network with more heterogeneous degree distribution. In modeling the propagation of opinions, the diffusion of innovations and the adoption of behaviors, the Watts threshold model is well recognized as the fundamental model. Similar to the epidemic spreading dynamics, researchers have explored the social contagion on complex networks based on Watts threshold model for two aspects. One is to reveal the effects of network topology and the other is to understand the mechanisms of diffusion at the individual-level. Clustering measures the edge density among neighbors of an individual, which plays a key role in epidemic spreading. One manifest conclusion is that high clustering will suppress the epidemic spreading, leading to the increase of the epidemic threshold and the decrease the infection size [84, 153] . In investigating the effect of clustering on the adoption of behaviors, Ikeda et al. [287] studied the Watts threshold model on a clustered network generated from a projection of bipartite graphs and compared it to a non-clustered network with the same degree distribution. Similar to the spreading of health behavior [252, 253, 254] , the global cascades occur more easily on clustered networks than on non-clustered networks [287] . Hackett et al. [288] explored the cascade on the clustered networks produced by the configuration model with adjustable clustering [158] , and found there exists a range of k in which increasing the clustering of the network results in the increase of the mean cascade size, while out of this range it will decrease the mean cascade size. Hackett and Glesson [289] further explored the cascade phenomena on the highly clustered clique-based graphs [290] and obtained the closed-form expression for the final fraction of active nodes inside a clique of arbitrary size.

The social networks are mostly assortative, while the technological and biological networks are usually disassortative [136, 137] . Glesson [291] studied the Watts threshold model on the correlated networks and put forward an analytical approach to compute the mean cascade size. Dodds and Payne [292] developed generating function method which can not only calculate the mean cascade size, but also obtain the probability that a randomly chosen seed will trigger a global cascade. Besides, they also validated the theoretical results in the random networks with bimodal degree distributions. Payne et al. [293] studied the Watts threshold model on degree-correlated random networks by numerical simulations. They found that increasing the positive degree-degree correlation of the network will expand the global cascade regions. Besides, the degree-degree correlations impact the relationship between initiator' degree and its ability to trigger large cascade.

Galstyan and Cohen [294] studied the linear threshold model on a network composed of two loosely coupled communities. They found if the seeds are contained in one of the communities initially, the peaks of the activation dynamics in each community are well-separated in time. Curato and Lillo [295] used the linear threshold model to explore the optimal structure of a network consisting of two communities which can maximize the asymptotic extent of the diffusion. They found the optimal structure can be assortative, core-periphery or even disassortative when the average degree and the fraction of initiators are constrained. In looking for a minimal fraction of initially seeds needed to trigger a global cascade, they showed that the optimal network is a very dense community linked to a much more sparsely connected periphery. The impact of community structure on the cascade processes based on the Watts threshold model has been theoretically studied by Nematzadeh et al. [296] . They constructed a network model with two homogeneous modules, where the internal connectivities of the two communities are the same, and one parameter, i.e., the fraction of edges between the two communities, is used to control the strength of the community structure. The optimal network modularity is existed, at which the cascade size is maximized. This study has been extended to the case of the network with multiple modular communities [297] , where the similar results are found that the modular structures facilitate cascade and the optimal modularity is existed.

The above are the recent progresses about the effects of the network topologies on social contagions. In the following, we will introduce the impacts of different network models, including the weighted [178, 183] , the temporal [30, 201, 202] and the multiplex [28, 43] models on social contagions.

Weighted networks provide the meaningful representations of the strengths of the interactions between entities in the real world [183] . However, only a couple of works have studied the Watts threshold model on weighted networks. Hurd and Glesson [298] studied the Watts threshold model on weighted networks, where the weight of an edge depends on the degrees (e.g., k and k ′ ) of its nodes and is proportional to (kk ′ ) −αp . In the case of α p > 0 (α p < 0), the edge strength decreases (increases) as the increase of the product of the connectivities k and k ′ . In the case of α p > 0 (α p < 0), the edge strength decreases (increases) as the increase of the product of the connectivities k and k ′ . The cascade window (i.e., the range of k that global behavioral adoptions occur) is shifted to higher values when α p > 0 since highly connected nodes have relatively less influences on their neighbors. Unicomb et al. [299] found the heterogeneities of the weight distribution show the non-monotonous effect on the spreading dynamics, which can accelerate or decelerate the cascade processes.

In the real world, the interactions that trigger an individual to become active may come from the multiple ways [28, 43] . Brummitt et al. [300] generalized the Watts threshold model to the multiplex networks, in which a node becomes active if the fraction of its active neighbors in any channel exceeds a certain thresh-

where m i and k i respectively represent the number of active neighbors and the number of neighbors in channel i. Compared with contagion on the simple network that has the same topology but without considering the multiplexity, Brummitt et al. found that the multilayer network has a higher probability to encounter the global cascade. Yagan and Gligor [301] proposed a content-dependent linear threshold model for social contagion in multiplex networks. In this model, each edge type i is associated with a content-dependent parameter c i in [0, ∞] that measures the relative bias that type i has in propagating this content. An inactive node turns to be active if the total perceived influences, i.e., c i m i / c i k i , where m i and k i respectively represent the number of active neighbors and the number of neighbors in type i, exceeds its threshold φ. The authors showed that the content and edge types are important in characterizing the global cascade. Zhuang et al. [302] studied the content-dependent linear threshold model on the clustered multiplex networks, and found the clustering plays a double-faceted role on the cascade processes, where the clustering decreases the cascade size when the average degree of the network is small, while it facilitates the cascades when the average degree is large. Along this line, Lee et al. [303] studied the effect of individuals' heterogenous responses of Watts threshold model in multiplex networks. Two types of responses are introduced. In the first type, an individual becomes active if in at least one layer a sufficiently large fraction of neighbors is active. In the second type, an individual becomes active only if in every layer, the fraction of active neighbors is sufficiently large. They showed that varying the fractions of nodes following either rule facilitates or inhibits cascades. Furthermore, they found the global cascades become discontinuously near the inhibition regime, and the cascade size grows slowly when the networks density increases. Li et al. [304] explored the cross-layers cascade process in multiplex networks. They found the multiplexity speeds up the cascade if the additional layer can provide the extra short paths for the rapid spreading.

Karimi and Holme [305] modeled the cascades process in temporal networks, where individuals are only influenced by their contacts within a finite time window from the past to the present. The randomization of time stamps makes the cascade larger for the fractional-threshold mechanism [249] , while it makes the cascades smaller in the case of absolute-threshold mechanism [284] . Takaguchi et al. [306] also studied linear threshold model on empirical temporal networks incorporated with the decaying mechanism of the exposures and showed that the burst activity patterns facilitate the contagion. However, in another study of linear threshold model on the empirical temporal networks, Bachlund et al. [307] found that some networks support cascades, while some do not. Their further analysis manifested that there exists the competition between the inhibition effect of the burst activity patterns and the promotion effect of the timing correlations between contacts on adjacent edges. Some specific models incorporating the underlying mechanism that affects the behavioral adoption of individuals are also established. Melnik et al. [308] purposed a multi-stage social contagion model accounting for the fact that individuals in different stages of the spreading process exert different levels of influences on their neighbors, which can reproduce the multi-stage cascade phenomena. Liu et al. [309] considered a specific situation, where individuals in the network have several opinion leaders, who affect the behaviors of themselves markedly. The impact of opinion leaders makes the global cascades occur more easily, which can not only reduce the lowest average degree of the network required for the global cascade, but also increase the highest average degree of the network that the global cascade can occur. Kobayshi [310] generalized the Watts threshold model with the trend-driven mechanism, which introduces another type of nodes, the global nodes whose states depend on the fraction of the activated nodes in the population. When the fraction of activated nodes in the population exceeds a threshold, a trend emerges and the global nodes become active. Kobayshi showed that the global nodes accelerate the cascades once a trend emerges while their existences reduce the probability of the emergence of a trend. Accordingly, there exists a moderate fraction of global nodes that maximizes the average size of cascades. The persuasion mechanism which can strength the ability of the activated nodes' ability to convince his/her neighbors to adopt the behavior is also considered in the Watts threshold model purposed by Huang et al. [311] . They found such introduced mechanism can cause the networks to become more vulnerable to the global cascades, especially in the heterogeneous networks. Ruan et al. [312] generalized the Watts threshold model with mechanisms of spontaneous adoption and complete reluctance to adoption (i.e., immune or blocked node). They showed that speed of spreading depends strongly on the density of blocked nodes. When the fraction of blocked nodes is small, the spontaneous adopters are able to generate a large cascade. When the fraction of blocked nodes is large, since the spontaneous adopters dominate the spreading, only the small cascade can be generated and the spreading becomes slow. Juul and Porter [313] incorporated the synergy effects in Watts threshold model, and found the constructive synergy (i.e., the peer pressure experienced by a node is larger than it in Watts threshold model) speeds up the contagion process and the interfering synergy (i.e., the peer pressure experienced by a node is less than it in Watts threshold model) slows down the contagion process. Oh and Porter [314] accounted for the case that individuals will wait for some amount of time before they adopt a behavior. Their results indicated that heterogeneously-distributed timers can change the adoption order of nodes, either accelerate or decelerate the spread of adoptions.

Social reinforcement resulted from the multiple exposures of peer influence is the key feature of social contagions. In the above-discussed models, whether a node will be active depends only on the number of current exposures from its neighbors, free of memory effects. However, the historical records may be rele-vant, for example, the recent exposures may be more important than long-ago exposures. In such cases, memory plays a significant role and the dynamics becomes non-Markovian. To account for the memory effects, Dodds and Watts [315, 316] proposed a generalized threshold model, where each individual i contacts with one other individual j draw randomly from the population. If i is susceptible and j is infected, with probability β, node i receives a positive dose d i (t) sampled from a distribution at time step t. Each individual i maintains a memory of doses received over the previous T time steps, recorded by

Each recovered individual becomes susceptible with probability γ 2 in each time step. By adjusting the parameters, such as d i (t), d * i , β, γ 1 and γ 2 , this generalized threshold model can be reduced to the SIS, SIR, Watts threshold model, and so on. Specifically, when γ 1 = 1 and γ 2 = 1, the steady-state fraction of infected individuals φ * meets the following self-consistent equation

By analyzing the fixed points of Eq. (26), three universal classes of the equilibrium behavior are found (see Fig. 10 ). Further, when the length of memory T is fixed, the class that a particular system belongs to is only determined by p 1 and p 2 , which are respectively represent the probabilities that an individual will become infected as a result of one and two exposures.

Considering the non-redundancy of the received behavior information in social contagion, Wang et al. [317] put forward a non-Markovian susceptible-adoptedrecovered (SAR) social contagion model. In such a model, each individual can only be in one of the following three states: susceptible, adopted and recovered. Initially, ρ 0 fraction of individuals are randomly chosen in the adopted state, and the remaining individuals are set in the susceptible state. At each time step, adopted individuals transmit the behavior information to their susceptible neighbors with transmission probability β. Once an adopted individual v transmits the behavior information to its susceptible neighbor u successfully, the cumulative number of received pieces of information of u will be increased by 1 and at the same time individual v can't transmit the same information to u again, i.e., nonredundant information transmission. At time step t, assume a susceptible individual u of degree k already has m − 1 pieces of information, and once u receives another piece of information, the probability that it adopts the behavior is π(k, m). Therein, π(k, m) is a non-negative function of k and m, which has the largest value equal to 1. The adopted individual becomes recovered with probability γ. Individuals in the recovered state do not participate in the spreading dynamics. The edge-based compartmental theory is established, where a variable θ(t) represents the probability that individual v has not transmitted the information to a neighbor along a randomly chosen edge by time t. The evolution equation of θ(t) is written as

One main result is that the transition phase of the final adoption size on β can be changed from discontinuous to continuous, are shown in Fig. 11 . Zhu et al. [318] investigated the SAR model on weighted networks and found the heterogeneity of weight distribution always hinders the social contagion. Su et al. [319] proposed a reversible social contagion model on community networks, and found an optimal community structure that can maximize the spreading processes. Along this line, the SAR model was also studied in the time-varying community networks [320] , in which the hierarchical orders of behavior adoptions are uncovered. Shu et al. [321] explored the social contagion process on interdependent lattice networks, and showed that the phase transition can be changed from continuous to discontinuous by increasing the fraction of dependency links. The SAR model was also studied in the multiplex networks [322, 323, 324, 325] . Wang et al. [322] found that multiplex networks can promote the final adoption size. Zou et al. [323] considered different layers of multiplex networks have distinct reliability for social contagions. They showed that to increase the reliability of one layer can promote the contagion process. Wu et al. [324] found a double transition where a continuous transition occurs first and then followed by a discontinuous transition. Chen et al. [325] studied the SAR model on multiplex networks and assumed that a susceptible individual becomes adopted only if in every layer the number of adopted neighbors is equal to or exceeds the adoption threshold. They found the final adoption size will increase sharply with the information transmission probability when the adoption threshold is large.

Within the SAR model, there are many potential factors impacting the behavior adoption. Wang et al. [317] took the limited contact capacity of individuals in transmitting the information and suggested that enlarging the contact capacity makes the global adoption more easy to occur. Considering the heterogeneity of individuals, a binary threshold model is purposed in Ref. [326] , where some individuals have a low adoption threshold (i.e., activist), the remaining individuals however have a high adoption threshold (i.e., bigot). A hierarchical adopting phenomenon is observed, where the activists first adopt the behavior and then stimulate bigots to adopt the behavior. Besides, the model also shows the crossover phenomena in phase transition. Wang et al. [322] also explored individuals' heterogeneous credibilities in social contagion. Zhu et al. [327, 328] studied the local trend imitation within social contagion model, where both the tent-like adoption and the gate-like adoption probabilities are analyzed. Therein, the tentlike adoption means that the adoption probability is an increasing function of x (i.e., the fraction of adopted neighbors) when x is smaller than a certain value, and it becomes a decreasing function when x is larger than this certain value. The gate-like adoption, however, means that the behavior adoption probability is equal to 1 when x is in a range, while it equal to 0 when x is out of this range. For the tent-like case, they showed that the local trend imitation capacity impacts the phase transition, where a second-order phase transition is observed when the capacity is strong, while it becomes a first-order phase transition when the capacity is weak [327] . An optimal imitation capacity is found to maximize the final adoption size in the gate-like case [328] . Su et al. [329] proposed a susceptibletrial-adopted-susceptible (STAS) threshold model, where individuals in trial state are accepting behavior temporarily and can transmit the information. They found that the initial conditions of the dynamics affect the final state of the dynamics, which arises the hysteresis loop in the system. Wang et al. [330] considered that individuals communicate with multiple channels. When an individual is active in one layer, he/she can not use other channels to communicate since individuals cannot simultaneously use all communication channels. Time-delays occur and slow down the behavior adoption process, however it doesn't affect the final adoption size. Wang et al. [331] purposed a model, where time-delays are introduced before an individual to adopt a behavior when his/her fraction of adopted neighbors is equal to or exceeds the adoption threshold. They found the long time-delays induce a microtransition and it becomes sharper when the high-degree individuals have a larger probability experiencing time-delays.

Both the threshold model [284, 285, 249, 332] and the non-Markovian SAR model [317] only take into account the synergy effects, i.e., the reinforcement effects, of the susceptible individuals' direct neighbors. However, many evidences indicated that other infected individuals around a pair of susceptible-infected individuals would strength the transmission rate between them [333, 334] . Pérez-Reche et al. [335] purposed a generalized SIR model, where the transmission rate between an infected individual (donor) and one of its susceptible neighbor (recipient) depends on the neighborhood of this donor-recipient (d-r) pair, as

where α is a positive constant representing the basic rate of infection for an isolated d − r pair without synergy effects. The rate β d−r (t) quantifies the degree of synergistic effects. In the absence of synergistic effects, The rate β is of the same meaning as in r-synergy type. As shown in Fig. 12 , the epidemic threshold α is a nonincreasing function of β for both rsynergy and d-synergy. Pérez-Reche et al. also showed that the constructive synergy induces an exploitative behavior resulting in a rapid spreading process and the interfering synergy causes a slower and sparser exploitative foraging strategy that traverses larger distances by infecting fewer hosts. Within this framework, Taraskin and Pérez-Reche [336] found increasing the connectivity of a lattice will enhance the synergistic effects on spreading. Broder-Rodgers et al. [337] investigated the effects of both the r-synergistic mechanism and the network topology (by rewiring edges in the regular lattices) on the epidemic threshold of the SIR model. They found the network topology markedly impacts the spread. Under the strong constructive synergy, the systems becomes more resilient to the spread of the epidemic after more rewirings. However, rewiring always enhances the spread of epidemics when the synergy is destructive or weakly constructive if the local connectivity is low. Gómez-Gardeñes et al. [338] proposed an SIRS model where the recovered individuals can be reinfected. This reinfection mechanism affects the nature of its epidemic transition, which induces an abrupt transition, when the transmission rate for the reinfection (I + R → 2I) is larger than a critical value. Gómez-Gardeñes et al. [339] investigated the synergy effects of the neighborhood of the target ignorant receiver by using the SIS model, where the transmission rate from a transmitter j to an ignorant/healthy receiver i is λ j→i and its expression is written as

Therein, α accounts for the intrinsic value of the spreading phenomenon in the absence of the context, n h (i) represents the number of ignorant/healthy neighbors of the receiver i, and δ[n h (i)] is a function of n h (i) which captures the effect of the context. Gómez-Gardeñes et al. analyzed both the exponential relation and the linear dependence of δ on n h (i) and found the inhibitory mechanism (i.e., interfering synergy effects) leads to the explosive contagion that is not observed in the SIR model. Liu et al. [340] studied the constructive synergy of the spreader's context, where the transmission rate between a transmitter j and a receiver i is p(m j , α) = 1 − (1 − β) 1+αm j , with m j and α respectively representing the number of infected neighbors of the infected node j and the strength of the synergy effect, and β accounting for the basic transmission rate. Two theoretical methods are established, where the master equation is used to accurately predict the simulation results and the mean-field theory is adopted to give a physical understanding. Liu et al. obtained a critical strength

by the mean-field theory when the dynamical processes occurs on the random regular network with average degree k . When α > α c the steady-state density of the infected nodes exhibits an explosive growth versus the basic transmission rate and a hysteresis loop emerges. Hoffmann and Boguñá [341] purposed a synergistic cumulative contagion model which takes account the memory of past exposures and incorporates the synergy effects of multiple infectious sources. They found the interplay of non-Markovian feature and the complex contagion produce rich phenomena including the loss of universality, collective memory loss, bistable regions, hysteresis loops, and excitable phases.

Real-world social contagions usually interact with each other successively or simultaneously, which are thus named the ecology of contagions [65] . In this section, we will revisit the literatures on the interactions between two social contagion processes.

The studies of the two successively interacting epidemics are introduced in the previous section. In comparison, studies about two successively interacting social spreading processes are very few. Liu et al. [342] purposed a successively interacting social contagion model, where two behaviors, i.e., behavior 1 and behavior 2, spread successively on a network. The dynamical processes of both behaviors are depicted by a modified version of the SAR threshold model [317] , with a different behavioral response function. For the simplicity, let's denote λ 2 as the effective information transmission rate equal to λ 2 = β 2 /γ 2 . To determine the critical condition for the change of phase transition types (from continuous to discontinuous at the presence of inhibition effects, and from discontinuous to continuous at the presence of synergy effect), numerically solving Eqs (36), (38) and

Meanwhile, this discontinuous phase transition of behavior 2 can also be changed to be a continuous one when the effects of adoption of behavior 1 become synergistic (see Figs. 13 and 14) .

In real social networks, two behaviors may spread simultaneously and interact with each other. By analyzing the number of tweets versus time in Twitter music dataset, Zarezade et al. [343] found that the usage of Google Play Music is in the same rhythm with that of Youtube when a new album arrives to both systems, and a URL link becomes popular while the other receives less attention (see Fig. 15 ). The former implies the cooperative contagions which promote the spread of both adoptions of services, while the latter indicates the competitive contagion where the adoption of one behavior inhibits the other. A correlated cascades model is also proposed to predict users' product adoption behavior. By evaluating the prediction accuracy, Zarezade et al. claimed that the correlated model performs better than the models without consideration of the interaction between spreading processes.

Liu et al. [344] proposed a synergistic behavior spreading model on two-layer networks, where the SAR model was adopted to describe the adoption process of each behavior. In such model, behavior 1 and behavior 2 are assumed to spread on layers A and B respectively, where the adoption thresholds of the two behaviors are respectively equal to T 1 and T 2 . The synergistic mechanism is that the adoption of one behavior by a node in one layer enhances its probability of adopting another behavior in the other layer. Mathematically spreadking, once node i has adopted behavior 1 (2), it will generate an increase ∆T 2 (∆T 1 ) in the number of pieces of information about behavior 2 (1). For example, if a node has adopted behavior 2 and cumulatively it received m pieces of information about behavior 1 from distinct neighbors in layer A, this node will adopt behavior 1 if ∆T 1 + m ≥ T 1 . In the above equation, when λ = λ 1 = λ 2 and γ = γ 1 = γ 2 , the bifurcation theory was used to analyze the above equations. One interesting finding is that the synergistic interactions can greatly enhance the spreading of the behaviors in both layers. They also found the synergy effects alter the nature of the phase transition of the behavior adoption processes, in which a small (large) value of the transmission rate of behavior 1 (with small adoption threshold) can lead to a discontinuous (continuous) phase transition in behavior 2 (with large adoption threshold). Besides, with the synergy effects, a two-stage spreading phenomenon is observed that nodes adopting the small threshold behavior in one layer are more likely to adopt the large threshold behavior and further stimulate the remaining nodes to quickly adopt the behavior in the other layer. Chang and Fu [345] proposed a co-diffusion model for social contagion on a two-layer network which are respectively a periodic lattice and a random regular network. The model considers two aspects of the diffusion process. One is the inclusive adoption which allows individuals to adopt two behaviors (i.e., synergy adoption). At first, each naive individual (without adoption of any behaviors) becomes active with probability
i 1 and i 2 respectively represent the fractions of adopted neighbors of behavior 1 and behavior 2, K 1 and K 2 are constants, and α is a free parameter. If it is activated, then with probability
it adopts behavior 1, otherwise it adopts behavior 2. Once an individual adopts one behavior, it adopts another behavior with probability

α . The other is stochastic dormancy, which means an adopted individual will become dormant at any given time step with a given rate. When an individual is considering adoption, if a neighbor is dormant then this neighbor's influence is discounted. Chang and Fu found that lower synergy makes contagions more susceptible to global cascade, especially for those diffusing on lattices. Faster diffusion of one contagion with dormancy may block the diffusion of the other. Czaplicka et al. [346] explored the competition of the simple (SIS model) and the complex adoption processes (Watts threshold model) on interdependent networks. The interdependent networks consist of a simple adoption layer and a complex adoption layer, respectively corresponding to the layers which the SIS spreading process and the Watts threshold adoption process occur on. The interconnections between these two layers are added to couple the adoption processes. Czaplicka et al. found the transition points and the nature of transitions for both single dynamical processes are affected by the coupled dynamics. Specifically, the continuous transition can be observed in the complex adoption layer and the discontinuous transition occurs in the simple adoption layer, while in the previous studies [41] the SIS model and the Watts threshold model respectively exhibit continuous transition and discontinuous transition. Srivastava et al. [347] investigated two competing cascades modeled by a generalized threshold model on a signed network, with trust and distrust edges. They developed a pairwise analytical method to approximately calculate the probability of a node being infected at any given time. Srivastava et al. took the advantage of the derived solution to develop a heuristic method for the influence maximization problem, and showed that their proposed method significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art methods, particular when the network is dominated by distrust relationships.

In real world, multiple social contagion processes may compete or cooperate with each other and spread simultaneously. Such that, with the wide adoptions of social media and other socio-technical systems, the abundance of information to which we are exposed is exceeding our limited capacity [349, 350] . The information or ideas in different social medias must compete for our limited attention to become popular. To under the role of limited attention of individual users in the diffusion of memes, Weng et al. [348] developed an agent-based model and investigated how they shape the spread of information (see Fig. 16 for the illustration of the meme diffusion model). By turning the length of the time window in which posts are retained in an agent's screen or memory, they can change the extent of competition. For example, a shorter time window leads to less attention and thus enhances competition, while a longer time window allows for attention to more memes being noticed and thus decreases competition. By modeling the meme spreading on real social networks and random networks, they found the combination of social network structure and the competition for finite user attention is a sufficient condition for the emergence of broad diversity in meme popularity, lifetime and user activity. Glesson et al. [351] presented an analytically solvable model of selection behavior on a social network. They assumed each screen has capacity for only one meme, corresponding to the fierce competition. During each time step (with time increment ∆t = 1/N), one node i is chosen at random. Then node i innovates with probability µ and generates a brand-new meme, that appears on its screen and is retweeted to all i's followers. Otherwise, node i retweets the meme currently on its screen. When a meme is retweeted, its popularity is incremented by 1 and the meme currently on the followers' screens are overwritten by this meme. They found the competition among multiple memes for the limited user attention poises the system at criticality. For the network of degree distribution P (k) ∝ k −γ D , with 2 < γ D < 3, they derived the distribution of popularities at age a by q n (a) (i.e., a meme has been retweeted n times when its age is a) when a → ∞ as

Therein, B and C are the prefactors (see Ref. [351] for details). From Eq. (45), they showed that the popularity growth of each meme is described by a critical branching process, and the asymptotic analysis predicts power-law distributions of popularities with very heavy tails in the zero-innovation limit (µ = 0). Glesson et al. [352] further extended the above simplified model with the inclusion of memory times and the heterogenous user activity rates. Even this generalized model is more complicated, they showed that it is analytically solvable and is able to reproduce several important characteristics of empirical micro-blogging data on hashtag usage, such as the time-dependent heavy-tailed distributions of meme popularity. In modelling the collective behavior of users' decisions on adopting different software applications, Glesson et al. [353] put forward a model which incorporates two distinct mechanisms: one is associated with recent decisions of users and the other reflects the cumulative popularity of each application. They found various combinations of the two mechanisms that can yield the long-time behavior matched with the data. However, only the models that strongly emphasize the recent popularity of applications over their cumulative popularity can reproduce the observed temporal dynamics. Myers et al. [354] studied URL diffusion in Twitter and proposed a statistical model that allows for cooperation as well as competition of different contagions in the diffusion of retweeting behaviors. The competing contagions decrease the transmission rate of each other, while cooperating contagions help each other. By evaluating the model on the 18,000 contagions which are simultaneously spreading through the Twitter network, Myers et al. estimated the probability of a user being infected given a sequence or previously observed contagions, and also found that the interactions between simultaneous contagions will cause a relative change in the spreading probability of a contagion by 71% on the average. Valera et al. [355] used continuous-time Hawkes processes to model the adoption of multiple products and conventions. An inference method was developed to estimate the parameters for both the synthetic and real data. They found this data-driven model predicts the adoption and the usage pattern of competing products and social conventions well. Meanwhile, the model reveals that the usage of more popular products and conventions is triggered by cooperation and using a less popular product or convention has a stronger inhibiting effect on future uses of a more popular product or convention than vice versa. Pathak et al. [356] proposed a generalized version of the linear threshold model to simulate multiple cascades on a network. In the model, nodes are allowed to switch their states back and forth. An algorithm is developed to estimate the most likely stats of the cascades' spread and shown to be with high quality tested in real data.

When an epidemic spreading in the society, the information about the disease will spread through various kinds of communication platforms, such as TV news, Facebook, Twitter, short message, phone calls, WeChat, and so on. Once the healthy individuals obtain the information about the epidemic, they will be aware of the epidemic and thus take some actions (e.g., wearing face masks or staying at home) to protect themselves from being infected by the disease, which will effectively suppress the outbreak of the infectious disease. To understand how awareness spreading (also called information spreading in the literature) can mitigate disease outbreaks, and more broadly, the interplay between the two types of spreading dynamics has led to a novel research domain in network science [52] . When investigating the coevolution of awareness diffusion and epidemic spreading dynamics, scientists always assume that the susceptible individuals will take some non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs, e.g., hand-washing and social distancing) once they are aware of that they are in a dangerous circumstances, and thus the susceptible nodes will have smaller probability of being infected by their neighbors [357, 358, 359, 360] . Usually, the disease outbreak threshold increases and the infected size decreases when the interventions are implemented. Vaccination is another effective measure to suppress the spreading of infectious diseases [361, 362, 363] . In most cases, the effects of vaccination and NPIs on the epidemic spreading are investigated separately [364] . Andrews and Bauch [365] proposed a model which includes both the two measures, and revealed that the practice of NPIs decreases if vaccine coverage increases, and vice versa. In what follows, we discuss the recent progresses about the coevolution of awareness and epidemic on single and multiplex networks.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness diffusion and epidemic spreading

body_text.text: Google is one the most popular channels for persons to obtain the information about epidemics, thus the volume of related queries or the Google Flu Trends (GFT) should be highly correlated to the number of infected persons [366, 367, 368] . To study the coevolution mechanism in real data about information and epidemic, Wang et al. [369] investigated the weekly series of information and epidemic about the influenza-like illness (ILI) synchronously evolving from 3 January 2010 to 10 December 2013 (nearly 200 weeks) in the United States. The data set records the weekly query volume for searching ILI symptoms from the Google Flu Trends (GFT) and weekly visits of outpatients to hospital [368] . Fig. 17 reported the time series of n G (t) (i.e., the number of ILI) and n D (t) (i.e., the volumn of search query). From the perspective of macroscopic, ILI and GFT have similar trends, as shown in Fig. 17(a) . The time series are further analyzed from a view of microscopic. Define the relative growth rates of n G (t) and n D (t) as v G (t) and v D (t) respectively, which are given by
and

The growth trends of v G (t) and v D (t) are the same, as shown in Fig. 17(b) . Furthermore, the cross-correlation c(t) between the time series of v G (t) and v D (t) for a given window size W l that defined in Ref. [370] are investigated. The cross-correlations c(t) is the Pearson correlation between the two time series {v G (t), v G (t + 1), · · · , v G (t + W l )} and {v D (t), v D (t + 1), · · · , v D (t + W l )}. As shown in Fig. 17(c) , both the positive and negative c(t) are unveiled for W l = 3 and W l = 20, respectively. Once the susceptible individuals received information through GFT, they will adopt some actions to protect themselves from being infected, thus the opposite growth is observed. For the infected individuals, they trend to search some information about the disease, which leads to the same growth trends. Furthermore, Wang et al. found that the asymmetric interaction (i.e., the epidemic spreading promotes information diffusion while information diffusion suppresses the epidemic spreading) between information diffusion and epidemic spreading only existed in a short period, as shown in Fig. 17(d) .

Zhan et al. [371] analyzed the coevolution of information and two representative diseases (i.e., H7N9 and Dengue fever). They collected the daily data about the two diseases from Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention, and crawled the information data about diseases from Sina Weibo. For individuals who got the information about the disease, they will be aware of the disease, and may take some actions to protect themselves from being infected. Through empirical analyses and mathematical modelling, Zhan et al. claimed that the awareness and epidemic will asymmetrically affect each other. Similar results are also reported in Refs. [369, 372] .

Funk and his colleagues investigated a variant SIR model that considers the coevolution of awareness and disease on well-mixed populations and lattices [59] . In their proposed model, the information about disease is called as awareness. An individual i with awareness level ℓ i represents that the awareness has undergone ℓ i individuals before arriving at i, ℓ i = 0 means that individual i has the first-hand awareness. The awareness level of individual i is updated according to the following three rules. (i) A new awareness ℓ i = 0 is generated with probability ω if individual i is in the infected state. (ii) If individual j transmits a newer piece of awareness with level ℓ j to his/her neighbor individual i with rate α, updating ℓ i ← ℓ j + 1 when ℓ j < ℓ i . (iii) At each time step, the awareness level ℓ i of node i fades to ℓ i +1 with probability ǫ. For a susceptible node with awareness level ℓ, its susceptibility is 1 − h ℓ , where 0 < h < 1. That is to say, the older the awareness (i.e., the higher level) is, the weaker the protection power is. With the considering of awareness, the SIR epidemic evolves as follows. An infected node transmits the infection to a susceptible neighbor of awareness level ℓ with probability (1−h ℓ )β, and recovers with probability γ. By using a mean-field approach, the authors revealed that the outbreak threshold is not changed in well-mixed population, while the epidemic size is much lower than the one without awareness. However, the epidemic outbreak threshold increases on highly structured networks, such as lattices. As shown in Fig. 18 , in the snapshot, the infected nodes are surrounded by the cloud of awareness, which greatly suppresses the epidemic spread.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on single networks

body_text.text: Funk et al. [373] further considered a more complicated case where the epidemic spreading is characterized by a classical epidemic susceptible-infectedrecovered-susceptible (SIRS) model [15] with infection, recovery and loss of immunity probabilities being β, γ, and δ, and the awareness spreading is described by a generalized SIS model, in which an infected node becomes aware with probability ω, an aware node transmits the awareness to unaware neighbors with probability α, and an aware node loses awareness with probability λ. The dynamical parameters dependent on whether nodes are aware of the epidemic information. (i) Figure 18 : (Color online) Snapshot of awareness and epidemic spreading on triangular lattice. Red represent nodes in the recovered state, light red stand for nodes are in the infected state, and darker gray means nodes have higher level of awareness. Reproduced from Ref. [59] .

The recovery probability of aware infected node is εγ. (iii) Longer preservation of immunity. For unaware recovered node, the probability of loss immunity is δ; and for aware recovered node, the probability of loss immunity is φδ. With the above three modifications, the basic reproductive number R d 0 of the epidemic is different for distinct situations. If the susceptibility of susceptible node is reduced, R d 0 is only dependent on the basic reproductive number R a 0 of the awareness. To sum up, the epidemic threshold will increase if the infection and recovery rates are changed because of the diffusion of awareness. Agaba et al. [374] proposed a model where the awareness is induced by two aspects: direct contacts between aware and unaware nodes and public information, and revealed distinct dynamical regimes. Ruan et al. [375] assumed that the awareness can be generated by the information transmission, which is described by the delivery of information packets. A susceptible-infected-recovered-vaccination (SIRV) model is proposed to describe the epidemic spreading dynamics. Mathematically, the SIR component of the spreading dynamics is identical to the classical SIR model with infection and recovery probabilities being β and γ respectively. A susceptible node becomes vaccination with probability κ(t). Nodes in the recovery and vaccination states do not participate in the spreading dynamics. At each time step, there are τ N newly generated packets with a randomly chosen origins and destinations, following a shortest-path routing protocol [376, 377, 378] . At time t, if a node receives m I (t) packets from infected neighbors, it becomes vaccination with probability

[375] found that the final epidemic size ρ R (∞) monotonously changes with vaccination ρ V (∞) as shown in Fig. 20 . Specifically, the epidemic may outbreak globally or locally for small vaccination, which is markedly different from other classical immunizations approaches, e.g., random, degree-based, and betweenness-based approaches.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on single networks

body_text.text: Mass media, e.g., TV, news, broadcasts, is an important measure to distribute the information about the epidemic, and has observably effects on controlling infectious epidemics [379, 380, 381, 382, 383] . Some studies considered the coevolution of awareness and epidemic on well-mixed populations [384, 385, 386] , in which the awareness is generated by mass media. Some interesting phenomena are observed when the awareness spreading is induced by mass media, such as the sustained oscillation may occur if the awareness is larger than a threshold [384] . Wang et al. [387] investigated the effects of mass media on the spread of epidemic on complex networks, where the epidemic spreading is described by the SIS model. The mass media density is a linear function of the current epidemic prevalence. Mathematically, using the heterogeneous mean-field theory to describe the evolutions of mass media M(t) as

The term kM α+kM is the media coverage function. On the right hand of Eq. body_text.text: Their results indicate that the mass media is an effective tool in controlling the global epidemic outbreak. Another line about the awareness-epidemic spreading dynamics assumed that the awareness is correlated with neighbors, such as, the number of infected neighbors [357, 358, 359, 360, 389, 390, 391, 392, 393, 394, 395] . The nodes which are aware of the epidemic will decrease their infectivity probability [357, 396] or activity [397] . In this case, the evolution of awareness is directly determined by the evolution of epidemic. Thus, we only need to write down the evolution equations of the epidemic. Zhang et al. [359] proposed an awareness-epidemic model, in which the awareness of a susceptible node is determined by the number of its infected neighbors. In this model, a susceptible node with awareness has smaller infectivity probability, i.e., the infection probability is λ(1 − α r ) n I , where λ is the basic infection probability, α r is the reduction factor, and n I is the number of infected neighbors. Zhang et al. used the heterogeneous mean-filed theory to describe the spreading dynamics, and found the outbreak thresholds of SIS and SIR models are the same, which is

body_text.text: From Eq. (55), once can observe that the stronger awareness is the larger outbreak threshold is.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on single networks

body_text.text: To describe the belief and vaccination decision of individuals, Xia and Liu proposed a novel model [398] , that assumes that an individual's belief about the severity and vaccine safety of epidemic is updated according to the received awareness from neighbors. Two key factors determine the adoption of vaccination. The first factor is the fraction of nodes infected by the epidemic and being vaccinated, and the second factor is the fading of awareness [59] . The authors found that the first factor affects the fraction of vaccinated nodes, and the second factor influences the time when the nodes become vaccinated.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on single networks

body_text.text: Time-delays are pervasive real-world networked dynamics and can radically alter the evolution of dynamic processes in networks [331, 399, 400] . Greenhalgh et al. induced the time-delays into awareness-epidemic coevolution spreading dynamics [401] . On the one hand, the awareness of individuals disappears after experiencing some time steps τ 1 . On the other hand, the strength of awareness is dependent on the number of infected individuals at time t − τ 2 since the policy maker makes decisions based on previous reports about the epidemic. Once the time-delays are included, the system will exhibit limit cycle oscillation. Agaba et al. [402] assumed that the time-delays are induced when nodes became aware and modified their behavior.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on single networks

body_text.text: In the above subsection, scientists studied the case where the awareness and epidemic spread on the same network. However, a usual case is that the epidemic spreads on contact networks, such as sexual webs, while the awareness spreads on various kinds of social communication platforms, e.g., Twitter and Facebook. Thus, using multiplex networks to describe coevolution spreading of awareness and epidemic is more realistic. In this subsection, we will introduce the progresses of the coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks

body_text.text: Granell et al. [403] proposed an unaware-aware-unaware+susceptible-infectedsusceptible (UAU+SIS) model on multiplex networks to describe the coevolution of awareness diffusion and epidemic spreading, where nodes in the multiplex networks are matched one-to-one randomly. The awareness spreads through virtual contact following an UAU model, in which each node can be in unaware or aware state. The evolution of awareness follows three rules: (i) Each unaware node will be infected by aware neighbors on the virtual network with probability λ 1 . (ii) Each unaware node will become aware if its counterpart in the physical network is infected by the epidemic. (iii) Each aware node will forget the epidemic information or relax its vigilance and become unaware with probability γ 1 . The epidemic spreads through physical contacts is described by an SIS model, following two rules. (i) Each susceptible node will be infected by infected neighbors with probability λ 2 = λ U 2 if its counterpart is in the unaware state in virtual network, otherwise it will be infected with probability λ ′ 2 = δλ U 2 , where 0 ≤ δ ≤ 1. (ii) Each infected node recovers with probability γ 2 .
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks
