If the awareness can not outbreak, the epidemic threshold reduces to λ 2 c = γ 2 /Λ max (B), which is the same with the classical epidemic outbreak threshold [92] . Granell et al. defined (λ 1 c , λ 2 c ) as the metacritical point of epidemic spreading. Through extensive numerical simulations, they found their developed MMCA approach agrees extremely well with numerical simulations, and the average accuracy of the approximation is about 98%. The phase diagram of the coevolution dynamics is shown in Fig. 22 for different values of γ 1 and γ 2 . The metacritical point is bounded
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks

body_text.text: The model proposed by Granell et al. [403] assumed that (1) the infected nodes immediately become aware, and (2) the aware nodes have a lower susceptibility with a certain probability. What will happen once the two assumptions are taken out? To this end, Granell et al. [405] proposed a novel model without the two assumptions but including a new fact, i.e., the mass media can broadcast the awareness [406] . A generalized MMCA approach is developed to describe the proposed model, and markedly well agree with numerical simulations. Granell et al. revealed that the first assumption almost has no effect on the epidemic spreading, while the second assumption and mass media indeed alter the phase diagram. For instance, the metacritical point will disappear if mass media is strong enough. Kan and Zhang included this mechanism into the coevolution of awareness and epidemic, and revealed that self-awareness generating (i.e., an unaware individual become aware spontaneously) can not alter the epidemic outbreak threshold [407] .
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks

body_text.text: In reality, the awareness spreading is different from the epidemic spreading. When an epidemic outbreaks, the information about the epidemic can spread on various channels such as Twitter, Facebook and short-message through mobile phones. However, the susceptible nodes may not arise the awareness immediately when they only receive one piece of information from neighbors [4] . Thus the awareness spreading exhibits social reinforcement or herd-like feature [408] . Guo et al. proposed a local awareness controlled contagion spreading (LACS) model to describe the coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks [409] . The Watts threshold model [249] is used to describe the awareness spreading, in which an unaware node becomes aware if (1) the fraction of its aware neighbors excesses a given threshold φ, or (2) it is infected by the epidemic. The aware node returns unaware when it is susceptible or relaxes its vigilance. For the epidemic spreading dynamics, they adopted the model proposed in Ref. [403] with a complete immunization, i.e., λ ′ 2 = 0. Using a generalized MMCA approach, Guo et al. obtained highly accurate of the epidemic threshold. Through extensive numerical simulations and theoretical analysis, the epidemic threshold λ 2 c versus φ exhibits abrupt decrease at φ c ≈ 0.5. For the case of φ < φ c , the epidemic size and outbreak threshold nearly do not change with φ. When φ > φ c , the epidemic do not vary with φ, but the epidemic size increases with φ. Huang et al. [410] investigated the coupled contagion of the awareness and the epidemic, where the former is depicted by the unaware-aware-unaware (UAU) model on the aware layer and the latter is elaborated by the threshold model (susceptible-infected) on the contact layer. The interacting mechanisms are introduced that an unaware individual immediately changes to aware state if it is infected in the contact layer. An susceptible individual can be infected by each of its infected neighbors with a certain probability if it is in unaware state. While for an aware and susceptible individual, only when the number of its infected neighbors is equal to or exceeds a threshold, it is infected by the epidemic. Huang et al. found such heterogenous interactions can induce the hybrid phase transitions which includes the coexistence of continuous phase transition and bi-stable states.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks

body_text.text: Heterogeneities of nodes are widely observed in many real-world systems, including the different degrees [36] , different adoption thresholds [326, 322] , and different waiting times [30, 411] . On the one hand, different nodes usually exhibit distinct responses when they know the information about the epidemic, therefore, the awareness spreading dynamics should be described by using a model with heterogeneous thresholds [412] . Pan and Yan [413] proposed a coevolution model of awareness and epidemic, in which the awareness of nodes comes from three types of information: contact information, local and global prevalence of the epidemic. The epidemic threshold increases with the contact-based information, but does not change with the information about the local and global prevalence of the epidemic. Furthermore, the effects of the heterogeneities of individuals' responses, structures of virtual and contact networks are investigated, and the existence of two-stage effects on the epidemic threshold are demonstrated [413] . Zang considered the awareness transmission probability equals to the fraction of nodes in the aware state, and found that the epidemic spreading is greatly suppressed [414] .
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks

body_text.text: Since the transmission probability of epidemic may be time-varying [415, 416, 417] , Sagar et al. [418] proposed a generalized UAU+SIS model, in which the transmission probabilities of awareness and epidemic vary with time. The system can be in one of the sustained oscillatory and damped dynamics. For the case of damped dynamics (i.e., endemic state), the epidemic is greatly suppressed if the awareness spreading is included. Their results were further verified by using a generalized MMCA approach. In addition, the evolution time scale is fatal for the coevolution spreading dynamics [218] . Wang et al. [419] investigated the effects of time scale on the coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks. Compared with the model in Ref. [403] , Wang et al. introduced a new parameter to adjust the relative speed of awareness and epidemic, and assumed the infected nodes in the contact network may not become aware instantly in the virtual network. An individual-based mean-field approximation method and MMCA approach were applied to analyze the coevolution dynamics, and found distinct accuracies for different time-scales, suggesting the existence of an optimal time scale, at which the epidemic will be greatly suppressed.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks

body_text.text: Most previous studies about the coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks assumed that the time scale of the network evolution is much longer than the spreading dynamics. Thus, the network topology can be treated as static networks. However, abundant experimental studies indicated that the network topology is varying during the spreading process [30, 201] . Guo et al. [420] assumed that the virtual network varies faster than the awareness spreading, and the contact network varies slower than the epidemic spreading. Therefore, the activity-driven network [202] is used to describe the virtual network, and the contact network is still assumed to be static. Then the awareness spreads on this temporal network according to the UAU model as proposed in Ref. [403] . The epidemic spreading dynamics on contact network evolves as the model in Ref. [202] . Through a generalized MMCA approach, Guo et al. found that the metacritical point is bounded by [0, 1/(m( a + a 2 )) × [0, 1/Λ max (B)], where a and a 2 are the first and second moments of activity potential distribution. If the awareness spreading dynamics follows a threshold model, the epidemic threshold versus φ exhibits a sharp decrease at φ ≈ 0.5, which is similar to the results in Ref. [409] . In addition, the time-varying of the virtual network promotes the epidemic spreading on the contact network.
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks

body_text.text: Different from the reversible SIS model, some epidemics such as measles and chickenpox should be described by using the irreversible SIR model [2] . Wang et al. [421] assumed that the awareness spreads on a communication network (layer A), and the irreversible epidemic transmits through a contact network (layer B), as shown in Fig. 23 . For the awareness spreading dynamics, they used an SIRlike model. Specifically, each aware (or infected) node transmits the awareness to unaware (i.e., susceptible) neighbors with probability λ 1 , and recovers with probability γ 1 = 1. The unaware node will be aware about the epidemic when its counterpart in the contact network is infected by the epidemic. For the epidemic spreading dynamics, a susceptible-infected-recovered-vaccination (SIRV) model is adopted. The infected nodes will transmit the infection to susceptible neighbors with probability λ 2 , and recovers with probability γ 2 = 1. A susceptible node i B in layer B will become vaccination if its counterpart in layer A becomes aware. To quantificationally describe the coevolution spreading dynamics, Wang et al. developed a generalized heterogeneous mean-field theory. The rate equations of the awareness spreading are

The parameter Θ A (t) = k 1 (k 1 − 1)P A (k 1 )ρ A k 1 / k 1 is the probability that an edge connects to an aware neighbor at time t, k 1 is the average degree of the network A, P A (k 1 ) and P B (k 2 ) are the degree distributions of layers A and B respectively. To obtain the outbreak threshold λ 1 c of the awareness spreading, Wang et al. used a linear approximation method, and got

If the awareness does not outbreak, i.e., λ 1 ≤ λ 1 c , the epidemic outbreak threshold is λ 2 c = k 2 /( k 2 2 − k 2 ), which is the same with that when there is no awareness spreading [86] . When λ 1 > λ 1 c , there are two different situations: (i) If the epidemic spreads faster than the awareness, i.e.,

body_text.text: If the awareness spreads faster than the epidemic, i.e., λ 2 k 1 /( k 2 1 − k 1 ) < λ 1 k 2 /( k 2 2 − k 2 ), the threshold is
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks

body_text.text: where S A is the fraction of the aware nodes in layer A, which can be obtained by using the bond percolation theory [86] . In simulations, the communication network is generated by using the scale-free (SF) uncorrelated configuration model [422] , and the contact network is ER network. This coupled network is thus called as SF-ER networks (i.e., the communication network is scale-free and the contact network is an ER network) hereinafter. As shown in Fig. 24 , the theoretical predictions agree well with simulations. One can observe that the final awareness outbreak size R A increases with λ 1 and λ 2 , while the final epidemic outbreak size R B decreases with λ 1 . Juher and Saldaña investigated the effects of overlap of two layers on the coevolution of awareness and epidemic [423] , and found the epidemic outbreak threshold is dependent on the fraction of overlap edges between two layers. In reality, immunization is always expensive and risky [424, 97] . For rational individuals, they will verify the necessity before adopting immunization. Along this line, Wang et al. [369] generalized the model proposed in Ref. [421] and assumed that a susceptible node adopting immunization should consider two aspects: (i) whether its counterpart in the communication network is aware of the epidemic, and (ii) whether the number of its infected neighbors in the contact network is larger than a threshold φ. Using the heterogeneous mean-field theory, Wang et al. showed that the awareness outbreak threshold is identical to that in Eq. (66) . However, the epidemic outbreak threshold is the same with that there is no awareness spreading on the communication networks when φ ≥ 1. While if φ = 0, the epidemic threshold is identical to that in Eq. (67) . Through extensive numerical simulations and theoretical analysis on different types of artificial multiplex networks, Wang et al. found that there is an optimal awareness transmission probability λ o 1 at which the epidemic will be greatly suppressed, as shown in Fig.  25 .
body_text.section: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on multiplex networks

body_text.text: Most of the previous studies assumed that individuals adopting the vaccination or immunization behavior only depend on their current perceptive awareness about the epidemic. Liu et al. [425] proposed a non-Markovian model that assumes the probability of adopting immunization behavior is dependent on the cumulated awareness, say ξ M = ξ 1 + (1 − ξ 1 )[1 − e −α(M −1) ], where ξ 1 is the basic vaccination probability when a node receives the first piece of awareness on communication network, and α > 0 is used to reflect the strength of social reinforcement: the larger α corresponds to the stronger social reinforcement. By using the heterogeneous mean-field theory, Liu et al. showed that the awareness outbreak threshold is identical to that in Eq. (66) , namely the social reinforcement has no effect on the threshold of awareness spreading. For the epidemic outbreak threshold, there are two different situations. (i) If the awareness can not outbreak on the communication network, the epidemic outbreak threshold is λ 2 c = k 2 /( k 2 2 − k 2 ). (ii) If the awareness outbreaks and the epidemic spreads faster than the awareness, the epidemic outbreak threshold will not be changed, otherwise the epidemic outbreak threshold is

body_text.text: The treatment of epidemic and the control of epidemic require human intervention, which is infeasible without the resource input from the government or other institutions. Thus, the effect on resource input in coping with the epidemic propagation is an issue of great social significance. A recently emerging research domain named economic epidemiology [426] , is mainly interested in the occurrence of infectious epidemics and the effects of public health interventions designed to control them. The possibility of eradicating epidemics, as well as the welfare loss induced by epidemics are highlighted. In the area of public health, there are some outstanding studies about the government resource input in coping with the epidemic spreading [427] . It is found that sharing the resource of antiviral drugs among the countries helps to contain the epidemic outbreak at the global level, and the more cooperative the resources, the more effective are the containments in all regions of the world. It has been pointed out that the lack of resource allocation can arouse critical financial crisis. For example, the scarcity of a resource is closely related to the susceptibility of the trade network with respect to cascading shocks [428] . However, the critical effect of resource on the epidemic-resource coevolution processes comes to the fore only recently.
body_text.section: Coevolution of resources diffusion and epidemic spreading

body_text.text: The resources (e.g., vaccines, fundings and human beings) for curing an infectious epidemic are always limited and expensive. Given limited resources, how to effectively allocate them is extremely important [429] . For instance, we can randomly allocate the resources to infected individuals, or prefer to allocate resources to some important individuals and areas, then how to find the important individuals to allocate the resource becomes a related optimization problem. Moreover, the critical phenomena of epidemic spreading dynamics could be different under different strategies for resource allocation. In this section, we first introduce the progresses of the influences of constant resources on the evolution of epidemic spreading dynamics, and then discuss the critical phenomena that induced by constant resources.
body_text.section: Epidemic spreading dynamics under constant resources

body_text.text: In the view point of macroscopic resource cost in the vaccination and the social welfare loss associated with the epidemics, Francis et al. [430] solved an optimal control problem of suppressing the epidemic through vaccination while minimizing the total cost. The resource regulation effects from both government policy and market were discussed. In a more realistic scene, the resource allocation is performed on spatial districts. For example, the epidemic outbreaks may occur in different but interconnected regions. Under this setting, Mbah et al. [431] studied an optimal control model to minimize the discounted number of infected individuals during the course of an epidemic with economic constraints, and investigated the preferential treatment strategies. Their results indicated that when facing with the dilemma of choosing between socially equitable and purely efficient strategies, the optimal control strategy is not apparent but should be determined by many epidemiological factors such as the basic reproductive number,the efficiency of the treatment measure, etc. Apart from multiple populations from different regions, the resource allocation over multiple time periods are studied [432, 433] . Mbah et al. suggested that allowing for some reallocation of resources or funds over the time horizon, rather than allocating resources just once at the beginning of the time horizon, can lead to significant increases in health benefits.

Since the allocation on districts is preliminary and rough, to better quantity the effect of resources, one can further consider the case where resources are allocated on individuals in networks (such as distributing vaccines and antidotes to individuals throughout the network). Preciado et al. [434] proposed a model, where the infections rate of each individual can be reduced by distributing the vaccination resources to them (so that they become less infective). Considering the cost of the corresponding vaccination, a convex framework to find the optimal distribution of vaccinations to contain the epidemics in arbitrary contact networks is proposed. In a similar model with the mechanism that the resources can be used to reduce individual infection rates or/and to increase the recovery rates, Enyioha et al. [435] proposed a distributed alternating direction method of multipliers algorithm to solve this problem, and got a distributed solution in which agents in the network were able to locally compute their optimal allocations. In a more realistic case, the curing rate of each node is positively correlated to its medical resources, that is, the more resources given, the higher curing rate. Since the total amount of medical resources is limited, the average curing rate is thus fixed. By using the mean-field theory and Lagrange multiplier method, Chen et al. [436] analyzed how to best allocate the limited resources to each node so as to minimize the epidemic prevalence. On temporal networks, Nowzari et al. [437] assumed that the epidemic spreading can be suppressed by decreasing the strength or weight of edges when allocating the resources. This can be understood that, for example, the government might be able to decrease the edge weight by reducing interactions between two nodes, such as limiting the amount of transportation between two cities. Nowzari et al. further showed that this problem can be formulated as a geometric program and solved in polynomial time.

The optimal allocation can also be formulated in a mathematical view. Ogura et al. [438] focused on the mathematical problem of finding the optimal allocation of containment resources to eradicate epidemic outbreaks over the models of temporal and adaptive networks, including Markovian temporal networks, aggregated-Markovian temporal networks and stochastically adaptive networks. For each model, a rigorous and tractable mathematical framework to efficiently find the optimal distribution of control resources to eliminate the epidemic is developed.

Chen et al. [439] pointed out that limited and insufficient resources would lead to critical outbreak of epidemic, resulting in discontinuous phase transition. They regarded the relationship between the devoted resource R and the recovery rate γ. Introducing the effect of resource R into the susceptible-infected-susceptible dynamics, they built a novel epidemic model, based on the time varying recovery rate which dependent on the average resource shared by each infected individual. When the amount of resource is fixed, the overall recovery rate of the system will be negatively related to the infected population size ρ. It means that larger infected population causes less resource per infected individual share, and hence a smaller chance for the infected individual to recover. On the other hand, if the number of the infected population is constant, the recovery rate can be improved by properly increasing the investment of resource. Therefore, the recovery rate γ(R, ρ) is a monotonic increasing function of R and decreasing function of ρ.

Chen et al. [439] analyzed the cured rate empirically by studying the cholera. They found from the observed data that there is a strong evidence that the recovery rate is positively correlated to the average resource devoted to each infected individual. Analyzing the cured rate, the infected population size and the economic conditions of the respective countries, they found that the logarithm of the cured rate is linearly correlated with the infected population size divided by purchasing power parity (PPP) with negative slope. Sice cured rate above is essentially the recovery rate γ(t) of the system and the PPP can be considered as an index of the devoted resource R, the form of γ(t) is

To investigate the impact of resources, Chen et al. simulated the model on disparate real-world and artificial networks. In the final state, the disease can is either extremely widespread, or only a few nodes are infected. At the critical point of resource amount R c , a tiny change of R would make a huge difference in ρ(∞), the final infected proportion. Such abrupt transition indicates that adequate resource is required to suppress the epidemic spreading,which implies that the public resource expenditure shows a critical behavior.

In order to quantificationally uncover the origin of the discontinuous and hybrid phase transitions, a mean-field theory is successfully applied. Considering the simple case of random regular network with uniform degree k, where every node is indistinguishable from each other. The infected proportion ρ(t) is governed by the mean-field equation

where β is the infection rate. The first term of Eq. (70) represents the rate that a susceptible node is infected and the second term stands for the recovery rate. Unlike the classical SIS dynamics [440] , Eq. (70) could have multiple steady states that satisfy dρ(t)/dt = 0. This can be understood by introducing a potential function constructed from Eq. (70) as

This system has one unstable (local maximum or critical) point ρ c and two stable fixed (local minimum) points ρ l (∞) and ρ h (∞) which are separated by the Reproduced from Ref. [439] . unstable point ρ c as shown in Fig. 27 . Therefore when R is fixed, depending on the initial infected population ρ(0), the infected population size evolves to one of stable points.

For a given R, only when ρ(0) < ρ c the epidemic can be well controlled, otherwise the epidemic will breakout. On the other hand, this also indicates the existence of a critical resource R c for each initial condition ρ(0). The value of R c can be obtained by finding the local maximum point though the following two equationsρ(t) = dρ(t) dt | ρ(0) = 0 and ∂ρ(t) ∂ρ | ρ(0) > 0. When R < R c , the epidemic will be widespread, otherwise it will be effectively contained.

In real networks with heterogeneous topology, the phase behavior can be more abundant. In Fig. 28 (a) the abrupt jump size J(R c ) at the first-order transition point versus β is shown in simulations on a real-world sexual contact network. When β is large enough, the jump size J(R c ) at the critical resource value R c diminishes to 0. This means for large β, the infected population size drops continuously with the increases of devoted resource, yet discontinuously when β is small. Most importantly, for these networks with heterogeneous degree distributions, even if there is a single initial infected node [i.e., ρ(0) → 0], significant amounts of resource is required to contain the epidemic(see Fig. 28(b) ). For many real-world networks, the value of R c at ρ(0) → 0 is significantly larger than 0.

Three types of phase transitions: discontinuous, hybrid and continuous, can be observed. The catastrophic transitions (such as the discontinuous and hybrid phase transitions) occurs in the case with small spreading probability β, which usually corresponds to those fatal epidemics. Fig. 28(c) shows the regions for three distinct phase transitions determined by the value of β. The three phase regimes are separated by β c and β b . When β < β c , increasing resource R can always eradicate the epidemic spreading. Hence β < β c is the region of discontinuous phase transition, corresponding to Fig. 28(d) . When β > β b , the infected fraction changes continuously with R, this region is the continuous phase represented in Fig. 28(f) . When β c < β < β b , there is a hybrid phase transition. In this region, since β > β c , the epidemic can never be totally removed. At the same time, β < β b means as we increase resource R, the steady state ρ(∞) will jump from the upper stable point to the lower one at certain threshold, as shown in Fig. 28(e) .

Jiang and Zhou [441] proposed a generalized model on multilayer networks. They found a similar resource threshold, such that a significant fraction of the total population may be infected if the amount of resource is below this threshold. Moreover, the threshold is dependent upon both the connections between the lay-ers and their internal structures. It is found that the inter-layer connecting strength can lead to the phase transition from the discontinuous phase to the continuous one or vice versa, whereas the internal connecting strength can result in the hybrid phase transition apart from discontinuous and continuous ones. Thus, the links between the layers and the links within a layer play different roles in the resourceinduced critical phenomena. Since epidemic spreading naturally involves time delay due to the order of propagation, the effects of time-delays between the layers are discussed [442] . Interestingly, it is found that the time delay can induce discontinuous, continuous and hybrid phase transitions among them, depending on the resource amount, the connecting strength between layers and their internal structures. In addition, there is a critical threshold of time delay such that even a small resource amount can effectively control the epidemic spreading if the delay is beyond this threshold, otherwise a huge amount of resource is needed. Thus, the effect of time delay in the presence of limited resource is more important.

Another easy, fast and less expensive way to slow down the spread of epidemic is to make the population be aware of the epidemic and possible self-protecting methods. For this purpose, the government can allocate some funds to make public aware through mass media, print media, pamphlets, etc. The effect of the time delay in providing funds by the government to warn people is studied [443] . By stability theory of delay differential equations, it is found that the delay may cause stability switches, resulting in epidemic outbreaks.

The resource discussed above is not relevant to the network topology and thus it is a global resource. One can further consider the resource that is provided by the neighbouring individuals in the network. Such local resource can induce more abundant effects on the epidemic spreading process. In the model setting of Ref. [444] , the infected nodes can only recover when they remain connected to a predefined central node, that provides the resources through paths consisted of healthy nodes. Interestingly, two phase behavior is observed that the system converges to only one of two stationary states: either the whole population is healthy or it becomes completely infected. This gives rise to discontinuous jumps of different sizes in the infected population and larger jumps tend to emerge at lower infection rates. Long Chen et al. [445] considered a SIS model where the recovery rate is positively related to the resource provided by the healthy neighbours. They considered the cases that nodes with large degree tends to receive more (or less) resource. Through analysis and numerical simulations, they find that the virus spreading can be optimally suppressed if there is no such a relation between the node degrees and resource amounts they received. Under this optimal strategy, there will be a maximum outbreak threshold and minimum fraction of infected nodes. Moreover, they find that the uneven distribution of resource would lead to discontinuous phase transition in homogeneous network while heterogeneous networks always go through continuous transitions.

The coevolution process of epidemic and resources is more realistic in social networks. In the view of global (government) resources, the outbreak of epidemic will reduce the labor force as sick workers will lose their productivity, and thus decrease the resource output. In the view of individual resources, social individuals may distribute their resources to their sick friends. In all these cases, the amount of resources should be affected by the epidemic process. In a word, the evolution of epidemic spreading is affected by the amount of resources, and at the same time, the amount of resources is also influenced by the epidemic spreading. Unlike the case under constant resources, the dynamical evolution of resources can bring nontrivial effects on the spreading of epidemic. The researches on the epidemic-resource coevolution processes come to the fore only recently. In this coevolution process, the critical outbreak of epidemic epidemic depends on the evolution properties of epidemics, resources and the complex interplay among them as well as the network topology.

If an epidemic becomes more prevalent, it can limit the availability of the resources needed to effectively treat those who have fallen ill, since the recovery of sick individuals may depend on the availability of healing resources that are generated by the healthy population. In the budget-constrained SIS (bSIS) model [446] , the healthy individuals produce the resources while the infected individuals consumes resources to recover. Insufficient resources producing rate would induce the outbreak of the epidemic. Equivalently, epidemic spread out explosively if the cost of recovery is above a critical value. Surprisingly, this can occur even when the epidemic would die out without the resource constraint. The onset of explosive epidemics exhibits a discontinuous phase transition. In more details, as illustrated in Fig. 29 , the budget-constrained SIS model modifies the classical SIS dynamic by introducing a global budget b that can be increased by the number of healthy individuals per time step. There is a basic recovery process that is independent of the available budget, occurring at a rate γ 0 . Furthermore, each individual can recover through treatment and this requires a cost c. This resourcemediated recovery requires the budget. On the other hand, the rate of recovery through treatment is γ b f (b), where f (b) is a function of the budget, satisfying Figure 29 : Illustration of the bSIS model. Reproduced from Ref. [446] .
With the mean-field assumption, the dynamics of the fraction of infected individuals is given by

In the early stage, as shown in Fig. 30(a) , the common SIS behavior can be observed, which is in a budget-unrestricted situation. However, after a critical time t = t * the epidemic spreads explosively. Fig. 30(a) shows an explosive epidemic where the entire population is infected in the steady state [ρ(∞) = 1]. Furthermore, there is a discontinuous transition in the model parameters. For example, as illustrated in Fig. 30(b) , the transition is discontinuous in the basic reproduction number τ . Therefore, there is a jump, ∆ρ(∞), in the infection level (see Fig. 30(a) ). The discontinuity of this jump in the final infected fraction ρ(∞) has important implications for the resilience of the healthy system and the control of epidemic. It implies that small changes in the properties of the epidemic can abruptly shift the infection levels from a low one to a high one that is harder to control.

The effect of global resource can also be seen from the strategy of the usage of resource. Assume that each individual can choose to use the resource to vaccinate or otherwise not to vaccinate. Without vaccination, there is a possibility that they become infected and this would also result in cost to treat the epidemic. In this situation, the evolution of resource is reflected in the evolution of the strategy about how individual use the resource. The human behavior and the networkingconstrained interactions among individuals significantly impact the coevolution of the epidemic and the resource strategy. Zhang et al. [447] proposed a theoretical framework to study the coevolution of epidemic and the resources game. Taking into account the periodic outbreaks of flu-like epidemics and the limited effectiveness of vaccines, they studied models with seasonal updating and pre-emptive vaccination, in which individuals decide whether or not to get vaccinated before each epidemic season. The strategy for individuals is whether they vaccinate or not. Although it requires a cost to vaccinate, individuals also cost money to treat the epidemic if they are infected when they do not receive vaccination. Once the epidemic ends, individuals update their vaccination decisions for the next season by imitating the strategy of neighbors. The neighbor with higher payoff has higher probability to be learned, which is described by the famous the Fermi rule in game theory [448] .

By this rule, an individual, say i, updates his/her vaccination strategy by randomly choosing one of its immediate neighbors, say j, and adopts the strategy of j with the following probability determined by the payoff difference

where v i = 1 or 0 denotes the vaccination choice for individual i: either vaccinated or not, and P i is the current payoff of individual i at the current season. Without any subsidy, according to the costs of vaccination and infection, we have

where σ is a parameter characterizing the rationality of the individuals: higher σ implies more rational. By incorporating evolutionary games into epidemic dynamics, Zhang et al. investigated the effects of two types of incentives strategies: partial-subsidy policy in which a certain fraction of the cost of vaccination is offset, and free-subsidy policy in which donees are randomly selected and vaccinated at no cost. Under the partial-subsidy policy, the vaccination coverage depends monotonically on the sensitivity of individuals to payoff difference, but the dependence is nonmonotonous for the free-subsidy policy, referring to Figs. 31(c) and 31(d). Due to the role models of the donees for relatively irrational individuals and the unchanged strategies of the donees for rational individuals, the free-subsidy policy can in general lead to higher vaccination coverage, referring to Figs. 31(a)-(b). As speculated, for the free-subsidy case , the freely vaccinated donees (red points as shown in Fig.31(b) ) are randomly distributed in the square lattice and surrounded by many imitated vaccinators, forming vaccination clusters and leading to relatively large vaccination coverage as compared with the partial-subsidy case (see Fig.31 (a) ).

In fact, in an earlier work, Zhang et al. [449] already claimed that, the performance of the partial-subsidy policy is significantly better than that of the freesubsidy policy, because the partial-offset subsidy policy encourages more people to take vaccination. In the partial-subsidy scenario, with limited amount of total subsidy, a moderate subsidy rate for each vaccinated individual can guarantee the group-optimal vaccination, leading to the maximal social benefits, while such an optimal phenomenon is not evident for the free subsidy scenario. Regarding the cost in vaccination, Zhang et al. [450] further proposed a model where individuals are freely vaccinated according to either the targeted or random subsidy policy in advance, while the remaining individuals choose to vaccinate or not based on voluntary principle and update their vaccination decision via an imitation rule. Here, targeted subsidy policy means a fraction of nodes with highest degrees are freely vaccinated while random subsidy policy means that the freely vaccinated nodes are chosen randomly. It is found that the targeted subsidy policy is only advantageous when individuals prefer to imitate the subsidized individuals' strategy. Otherwise, the effectiveness of the targeted policy is worse than that of the random subsidy policy, since individuals preferentially select non-subsidized individuals as their potential imitation objects. More importantly, under the targeted subsidy policy, preferential imitation causes a nontrivial phenomenon that the final epidemic size increases with the increase of the proportion of subsidized individuals. In summary, epidemic-control policy through resource input depends on the complex interplay among the intrinsic mathematical rules of epidemic spreading, governmental policies, and behavioral responses of individuals. Moreover, this complexity may arise the so-called Braess's Paradox [364] such that increasing the strategy performance may in contrary lead to worse strategy outcomes (more resource to be consumed).

Similar to the Braess's Paradox, the increasing level of vaccine in the population helps to inhibit the epidemic spreading, which in turn, however, discourages more people to participate in vaccination campaigns, due to the 'externality effect' raised by vaccination. Cai et al. [451] studied the impact of different vaccination strategies on the epidemic spreading.The three strategies under consideration are (i) pure, (ii) continuous (rather than adopt vaccination definitely, the individuals choose to taking vaccine with some probabilities), and (iii) continuous with randomly mutation. Based on a spatial susceptible-vaccinated-infected-recovered Figure 31 : Epidemic dynamics with incentive vaccination strategy. Snapshots of the stationary state configuration in square lattices with partial-subsidy (a) and free-subsidy (b) policies. Other parameters are N = 10 4 , c = 0.5, σ = 1.0 and δ = 0.4. The vaccination coverage V (c) and epidemic size R (d) as a function of β in homogeneous small-world network. The insets show the differences in the vaccination coverage and epidemic size between the partial-subsidy and free-subsidy policies, V P − V F and R P − R F , respectively. Reproduced from Ref. [447] .

(SVIR) model, they showed that there is a crossover behavior of the final vaccine coverage between the pure-strategy case and the continuous-strategy case, and remarkably, both the final vaccination level and epidemic size in the continuousstrategy case are less than them in the pure-strategy case when vaccination is cheap.

In terms of the resource strategy game, Wang et al. [452] examined how two countries would allocate resources at the onset of an epidemic when they seek to protect their own populations by minimizing the total number of infected individuals over the entire time horizon. They modeled this situation as a game between selfish countries. It is shown that the best strategy for selfish countries is to allocate their resources to themselves to decrease their own effective reproduction ratio. Even though each country is selfish, a major global outbreak may still be avoided.

Chen et al. [453] proposed a coevolution spreading model where the epidemic and resources separately spread in a multilayer network. Each healthy individuals can generate a certain amount of resource per time step whereas the recovery of infected nodes depends on resources from its healthy neighbors in the social layer. Specifically, Chen et al. [453] assumed that infected nodes consume all of the received resources at each time step. Each healthy individual generates one-unit resource, which are distributed equally to infected neighbors, at the next time step. The recovery rate of node i is γ i (t) = µ r R i (t)/k i , where R i (t) is the resources that node i receives from its healthy neighbors, µ r ∈ [0, 1] is the coefficient representing the efficiency of resource support from neighbors. Infection rate is denoted as β and the final infected proportion is denoted as ρ respectively.

Chen et al. find that the heterogeneous network structure and the overlap edges may play nontrivial roles in this spreading process. Here, edge overlapping means two nodes have edges both in the contact layer and the social layer. Figs. 32(a) and 32(b) show the epidemic spreading in scale-free network with exponents γ D = 2.4 and γ D = 3.2. The hybrid phase transition in the steady infection size ρ is observed, exhibiting properties of both continuous and discontinuous phase transitions. As ρ increases continuously with infection probability β at β I inv , a small increase in β would induce a sudden jump of ρ at β II inv . Here, β I inv and β II inv are the first and second invasion thresholds. Therefore, there are three possible system states: (i) completely healthy, (ii) partially infected, and (iii) completely infected. This is different from the classical SIS model where there are only two possible final infected states. In addition, there are hysteresis loops in the phase transition. When the seed density is initially low, e.g., ρ(0) = 0.01, the epidemic breaks out at the invasion threshold β I inv . If it is initially high, e.g., ρ(0) = 0.9, the epidemic breaks out at the persistence threshold β per .

Figs. 32(c) and 32(d) show the infected density ρ as a function of β with two typical values m e = 0.2 and m e = 1.0. Here, m e is the fraction of overlapping edges. Note that when the edges of the two layers overlap completely (m e = 1.0) the infected density ρ smoothly increases from 0 to 1. When the fraction of edge overlap of the two layers is lowered (e.g., when m e = 0.2), a hybrid phase transition appears (see Fig. 32(c) ). The infected density ρ smoothly increases at β = β I inv and then the system is in a low epidemic state (β I inv < β < β II inv ) in which ρ slowly increases. Subsequently at β II inv , an small increase in β will cause an abrupt jump in ρ and the epidemic suddenly spreads throughout the entire system.

Mathematically, Chen et al. used a generalized dynamical message-passing approach based on the non-backtracking matrix B of contact layer, to approxi-mately compute the epidemic threshold. They defined a matrix J with element of J is J j→i,l→h = −δ lj δ ih µ r + βB j→i,l→h , with δ being the Dirac delta function. The system will enter a global epidemic region in which the epidemic grows exponentially if the largest eigenvalue of J is greater than zero. Thus the epidemic threshold is
where Λ J is the largest eigenvalue of J.

Chen et al. [454] further considered the case where the diffusion of resources has preferential tendency that the resource tends to spread to the nodes with higher (α p > 0) or lower (α p < 0) degrees, determined by a bias parameter α p . Specifically, denote φ i→j the resource transfer probability from node i to j and assume that this transfer probability is related to the degree of j, say

The preferential resource diffusion can change phase transition type subjected to infection density. When the strength of inter-layer correlation is below a critical value, increasing α p changes the phase transition from double continuous to single continuous. When the strength of inter-layer correlation is above a critical value, the phase transition first changes from multiple continuous to discontinuous and then to hybrid. There are hysteresis loops in the phase transition. Moreover, there is an optimal strategy at any given strength of inter-layer correlation where the threshold reaches a maximum and under which the epidemic can be maximally suppressed. In addition, the optimal controlling parameter α p increases as the strength of inter-layer correlation increases. Chen et al. [455] further considered a similar model with preferential resource diffusion where the resource received is proportional to the number of healthy neighbours. They found two distinct preferential effects. When the transmission rate is small, the resources of the healthy nodes should be allocated preferentially to the highly infectious nodes (nodes with more infected neighbors) to constrain the epidemic spreading. When the transmission rate is large, the resource allocation should be determined by the stage of epidemic spreading. Namely, in the early stage of the epidemic spreading, resources should be allocated preferentially to the highly infectious nodes similar to the case of small transmission rate while after the early stage, resources should be allocated to the less infectious nodes. With the individual resource diffusion framework, they further proposed a resource allocation strategy that can adaptively change with the current fraction of infected nodes and the epidemic can be maximally suppressed under the proposed strategy, which gives a novel viewpoint to the optimal epidemic control problem under resource constraint.

The coevolution of resources and the network topology is also an interesting problem. Aoki et al. [456] proposed an adaptive model where resources diffuse over a weighted network with edge weights adaptively varying depending on the resource distribution. They showed that under feasible conditions, the network robustly acquires scale-free characteristics in the asymptotic state. Interestingly, in the case that the system includes dissipation, it asymptotically realizes a dynamical phase characterized by an organized scale-free network, in which the ranking of each node with respect to the quantity of the resource possessed thereby changes ceaselessly. Since the coevolution of resources and the network topology exhibits abundant properties, the coevolution of resources, network topology and epidemic deserves further studies.

Studies of coevolution spreading dynamics are very popular in the field of network science, especially because of some recent empirical observations, which indicate that some collective phenomena can hardly be understood by using single contagion models and the ignorance of the coevolving nature may yield misleading results. For instance, why the global epidemic can be contained by once the awareness about the epidemic is induced, why a virus grows discontinuously in biology, and why an epidemic outbreak size exists bistable states for limited resources. Correct answers to those questions cannot be obtained by analyzing a single spreading process.

In this review, we presented the state-of-the-art of the progresses of coevolution spreading dynamics on complex networks. The landscape of the studies on coveolution spreading dynamics are presented in Fig. 6 . The two main classes of spreading dynamics are biology and social contagions, and the two types of coevolution spreading processes related to the controlling strategies are epidemicawareness spreading and epidemic-resource spreading. As in the early stage of the progresses of evolution spreading studies, many efforts are made in analyzing various factors that are known to play significant roles in the single spreading dynamics. In addition, most theoretical approaches introduced in this review are firstly developed to analyze the single spreading dynamics. This situation will last for years and then completely novel viewpoints and approaches may arise. In the so-called big data era, the increasingly available empirical data in social platforms (such as Twitter and Facebook) and biological systems makes us able to build some more realistic data-driven coevolution spreading models [39, 457] . For the existing works, most of the known interacting mechanisms between two spreading, such as synergy, competing and asymmetrical, have not been verified by empirical data. Whether those coevolving mechanisms are enough to capture main properties of real dynamics, or we still need more intricate interacting models are not yet clear to us. Therefore, we should first collect as more as possible related data. For example, to crawl the forwarding time series, the network topology and the personal information about new and products, and then to analyze the interacting mechanisms between those news and products. In a word, to reveal the representative features of real coevolution spreading processes from empirical data (or, more valuably but more difficultly, from designed experiments) is the most significant task before credible studies on mathematical models.

Another important aspect is that the coevolution spreading dynamics is largely affected by the network topology. To get analytical solutions of the coevolution spreading dynamics, most previous studies made some assumptions about the network topology, such as the network is large, sparse, local-tree like and static. Studies on single spreading dynamics have already indicated that each assumption markedly alters the spreading dynamics, therefore, we should systematically study the effects of network topology on coevolution spreading dynamics from the microcosmic, mesoscale and macroscopic views. Furthermore, the spreading on adaptive networks [48, 118, 119] that also incorporating the coevolution of network topology should be investigated.

In addition, the studies on human dynamics have revealed some inherent regularities of human behaviors, such as memory and burstiness in temporal activities [458, 459, 460, 461, 462, 463, 464, 465, 466, 467, 468, 469, 470] and heterogeneity in mobility patterns [471, 472, 473, 33, 474, 475, 476] , which remarkably influence the single spreading dynamics [477, 478, 479, 480, 481, 411] . Once the human dynamics is included, the interaction patterns and transmissibility among nodes will be affected, thus the coevolution spreading will also be affected. The temporal and spatial network representations [29, 47] , as well as the Monte-Carlo simulations may be useful tools in this direction.

The resilience of coevolution spreading is a potentially interesting topic. The resilience of a system is the ability to maintain its functions when some errors and attacks occur, or some environmental and dynamical parameters are changed [482, 483, 484, 485, 486] . Previous studies mainly focused on the resilience of single dynamics, such as epidemic spreading [487, 488] , biological dynamics [489, 490] , climate changes [491, 492, 493] and financial dynamics [494, 495] . Pananos et al. [496] studied the critical dynamics in population with vaccinating behavior by extracting data on measles-related tweets and Google searches. They revealed the critical slowing down and critical speeding up for coevolution dynamics, which is markedly different from single spreading. Since the resilience depends on the dynamical process, does there exist some common characteristics for the resilience of coevolution spreading dynamics? For a given coevolution spreading process, how to estimate its resilience?

To control the coevolution spreading dynamics, we should identify the most influential nodes, so that we can promote the spreading by letting these influential nodes be infected seeds or suppress the spreading by immunizing these nodes. For single spreading dynamics, some effective measures (e.g., H-index [497] and k-core [498] ) and algorithms (e.g., PageRank [499] , LeaderRank [500] , collective influence [89] and some heuristic algorithms [501] ) are proposed. More detailed progresses about vital nodes identification are presented in a recent review [45] . We should note that an effective vital node identification algorithm may not work for coevolution spreading dynamics. For instance, the nodes with high k-shell values are more likely to be the influential nodes, however, those nodes may inhibit the spreading when there exists asymmetrical interactions between two dynamics. Therefore, the vital node identification problem should be redefined and reanalyzed for the coevolution spreading dynamics.

Lastly, to our best knowledge, the existing theoretical approaches are originally designed for single spreading dynamics, and can only deal with some specific situations in coevolution spreading dynamics. Generally speaking, the dynamical correlations in coevolution dynamics are stronger and more complicated than those in single dynamics, which ask for novel theoretical approaches that may be based on but beyond the message passing approaches [98, 502, 99] . In our intuitions, the non-backtracking matrix [503, 504, 454] and the Hankel matrix [505, 506] may be useful tools in theoretical analysis.

FIGREF9.text: (Color online) Left panel shows randomization of clustered-lattice and random-network conditions in a single trial of this study (N = 128, k = 6). In each condition, the black node shows the focal node of a neighborhood to which an individual is being assigned, and the red nodes correspond to that individual's neighbors in the network. In the clustered-lattice network, the red nodes share neighbors with each other, whereas in the random network they do not.White nodes indicate individuals who are not connected to the focal node. Right panel presents fraction of health behavior adoption versus time through the clustered-lattice (solid black circles) and random (open triangles) social networks. (A) to (F) show six independent trials for different network size N and average degree k . Specifically, (A) is with parameters N = 98, k = 6, (B-D) are N = 128, k = 6 and (E,F) are N = 144, k = 8. The speed of the diffusion process is valuated by comparing the time required for the behavior to spread the greatest fraction reached by both conditions in each trial. Reproduced from Ref. [252].

FIGREF10.text: (Color online) Numerical analysis of Eq. (26). (a) Class I: Epidemic threshold. (b) Class II: Vanishing critical mass. (c) Class III: Pure critical mass. Dose sizes are lognormally distributed with mean 1 and variance 0.433, T = 10, and thresholds are uniformly set at (a) d * = 0.5, (b) d * = 1.6, and (c) d * = 3. Inset in (a): An example of a more complicated fixed point diagram. Here, T = 20, dose size is set to unity, f (d) = δ(d − 1) is the delta function, and d * = 1 with probability 0.15 and 6 with probability 0.85. Reproduced from Ref. [315].

FIGREF11.text: (Color online) The non-Markovian SAR model on ER networks. (a) Time evolution of the average densities of susceptible, adopted and recovered nodes. (b) Final adoption size R(∞) versus the effective transmission rate λ = β/µ for different adoption threshold T . (c) Simulation results of NOI (number of iterations) as a function of λ. The lines in (a) and (b) are the theoretical predictions. The parameters in (a) are set as λ = 0.8, ρ 0 = 0.1, T = 3, and γ = 0.5, while in (b) and (c), ρ 0 = 0.1 and γ = 1.0. Reproduced from Ref. [317].

FIGREF12.text: β d−r (t) = 0 and the model reduces to the simple SIR process. Two types of synergy are introduced in the model and the expression for β d−r (t) depends on the synergy type. When multiple donors challenge a recipient host (i.e., r-synergy type), β d−r (t) = β[n r (t)−1] with n r (t) representing the number of donors challenging a recipient host at time t. The rate β measures the strength of synergy which is constructive for β > 0 and interfering if β < 0. The other type of synergy (i.e., d-synergy) accounts for effect of other donors connected to a donor that is challenging a recipient host. For d-synergy type, β d−r (t) = βn d (t) and n d (t) represents the number of other donors at time t.

FIGREF16.text: (Color online) Visualization of correlated cascading behavior in real data. (left) Tweets with terms Google and Youtube in Twitter music dataset are synchronized most of the time. (right) Different URL shortening services. tiny.ly and tinyurl are cooperating while migre.me and j.mp are competing. Reproduced from Ref. [343].

FIGREF17.text: Illustration of the meme diffusion model. Each user has a memory and a screen, both with limited sizes. (a) Memes are propagated along follower links. (b) The memes received by a user appear on the screen. With probability β n , the user posts a new meme, which is stored in memory. (c) Otherwise, with probability 1 − β n , the user scans the screen. Then the user either with probability 1 − β m retweets a meme chosen from the screen, or with probability β m tweet a meme chosen from memory. (d) All memes posted by the user are also stored in memory.Reproduced from Ref.[348].

FIGREF18.text: (Color online) Weekly outpatient visits and Google Flu Trends (GFT) of influenza-like illness (ILI) since 10th December 2013 in the United States. (a) The fractions of outpatient visits n D (t) (blue line) and GFT n G (t) (red line) versus t. (b) The relative growth rate v D (t) (blue line)and v G (t) (red line) of n D (t) and n G (t) versus t, respectively. (c) Cross-correlation c(t) between the two time series of v G (t) and v D (t) for the given window size W l = 3 (blue line) and W l = 20 (red line). (d) The fraction of negative correlations f P (blue squares) and positive correlations f N (red circles) as a function of W l . In (a), n G (t) and n D (t) are divided by their average values respectively. Reproduced from Ref.[369].

FIGREF19.text: (Color online) The fraction of nodes ρ R (∞) in the recovered state versus the fraction of nodes ρ V (∞) in the vaccination state under different immunization approaches. The network size is set as N = 2000, the average degree is k = 6, the infection probability β = 0.06, and the recovery probability µ = 0.1. Reproduced from Ref.[59].

FIGREF21.text: (Color online) The epidemic threshold λ 2 c versus awareness transmission probability λ 1 under different values of γ 1 and γ 2 . The shaded rectangle represents the metacritical points, which is bounded by 1/Λ max (A) and 1/Λ max (B). Reproduced from Ref.[403].

FIGREF22.text: An illustration of the coevolution dynamics of awareness and epidemic on communication-contact networks. (a) Communication and contact networks. (b) At t = 0, randomly selecting node B 1 in layer B as the seed of epidemic spreading, and its counterpart node A 1 in layer A is the seed of awareness spreading. The remaining nodes are in the susceptible state. (c) At t = 1, node A 2 obtain the awareness from A 1 with probability λ 1 , and node B 2 is vaccinated with probability p. Node B 1 transmits the infection to B 3 with probability λ 2 , and node A 3 gets the awareness. Meanwhile, node A 1 and B 1 become recovery state. (d) At t = 2, all infected nodes are in recovered state. Reproduced from Ref.[421].

FIGREF23.text: Coevolution of awareness and epidemic on SF-ER networks. (a) The final awareness outbreak size R A and (b) the final epidemic outbreak size R B versus λ 1 and λ 2 . Other parameter is set as p = 0.5. The lines are theoretical predictions with λ 1 = 0.2, 0.5 and 0.9 in (a) and with λ 2 = 0.2, 0.5 and 0.9 in (b). Reproduced from Ref.[421].

FIGREF24.text: (Color online) Coevolution of awareness and epidemic spreading dynamics on different type of multiplex networks. (a) The awareness outbreak size R A , (b) the epidemic outbreak size R B and (c) the vaccination size V B versus the effective awareness transmission probability λ A = λ 1 /γ 1 on ER-ER, ER-SF, SF-ER and SF-SF multiplex networks with λ B = 0.5. (d) R A , (e) R B and (f) V B as a function of λ B = λ 2 /γ 2 with λ A = 0.5. Other parameters are set as φ = 2, p = 0.8 and k 1 = k 2 = 8. Reproduced from Ref. [369].

FIGREF29.text: The phase behavior of the bSIS model. (a) Coevolution of the proportion of infected individuals ρ(t) and the budget b(t) on the friendship network.
